Harm Mitigation in Recommender Systems under User Preference Dynamics

Jerry Chee jerrychee@cs.cornell.edu Cornell UniversityIthacaNYUSA ,Â  Shankar Kalyanaraman kshankar@meta.com MetaMenlo ParkCAUSA ,Â  Sindhu Kiranmai Ernala sindhuernala@meta.com MetaMenlo ParkCAUSA ,Â  Udi Weinsberg udi@meta.com MetaMenlo ParkCAUSA ,Â  Sarah Dean sdean@cornell.edu Cornell UniversityIthacaNYUSA Â andÂ  Stratis Ioannidis ioannidis@ece.neu.edu Northeastern UniversityBostonMAUSA
Abstract.

We consider a recommender system that takes into account the interplay between recommendations, the evolution of user interests, and harmful content. We model the impact of recommendations on user behavior, particularly the tendency to consume harmful content. We seek recommendation policies that establish a tradeoff between maximizing click-through rate (CTR) and mitigating harm. We establish conditions under which the user profile dynamics have a stationary point, and propose algorithms for finding an optimal recommendation policy at stationarity. We experiment on a semi-synthetic movie recommendation setting initialized with real data and observe that our policies outperform baselines at simultaneously maximizing CTR and mitigating harm.

Recommender Systems; Harm Mitigation; Amplification; User Preference Modeling
â€ â€ ccs: Information systemsÂ Recommender systemsâ€ â€ ccs: Human-centered computingÂ Social mediaâ€ â€ This is the ArXiv version of a KDDâ€™24 paper of the same name.

1. Introduction

The algorithm of choice for many recommender systems in production today is the classic top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k recommendation algorithm (Karypis, 2001; Deshpande and Karypis, 2004; Cremonesi etÂ al., 2010). In short, a top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k recommender uses a score function to rank items from a candidate pool and subsequently recommends the kğ‘˜kitalic_k highest-scoring items. Such recommendations also come with optimality guarantees: for example, if scores are proportional to a userâ€™s selection probabilities, top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k recommendations maximize the click-through rate (CTR)Â (Oh and Iyengar, 2019, 2021), i.e., the probability that the user will pick at least one item from the recommended set.

A prominent criticism against top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k recommendations (and, more generally, maximizing engagement) is centered around the concept of amplification (Kalimeris etÂ al., 2021), i.e., a feedback loop that arises between recommended content and user preferences. Adverse effects of amplification include decreasing content diversity and amplifying biasesÂ (Mansoury etÂ al., 2020; HuszÃ¡r etÂ al., 2022), as well as increasing the spread of misinformationÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2022) or extreme content (Restrepo etÂ al., 2021; Whittaker etÂ al., 2021). Recent studies also explore the impact of recommendations from a userâ€™s perspective: recommendations may create pathways that steer users towards radicalization (Fabbri etÂ al., 2022), polarization (Leonard etÂ al., 2021; Levin etÂ al., 2021) but may also aid the migration towards ever more extreme (Ribeiro etÂ al., 2020; Restrepo etÂ al., 2021) or even harmful contentÂ (Lin etÂ al., 2016; Smith etÂ al., 2022; Hou etÂ al., 2019).

Motivated by these concerns, we model a recommender system that takes into account the interplay between recommendations and the evolution of user interests. In doing so, our work follows a long line of research in understanding the interplay between recommender systems and user behavior (see, e.g., (kalimeris2021preference; lu2014optimal; dean2022preference)). Our goal is to understand (a) the impact of recommendations on pathways towards, e.g., more extreme or harmful content, and (b) how this impact should be accounted for when making recommendations. In particular, the fundamental question that we try to answer is how should recommendations depart from top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k/CTR-maximizing recommendations when user preference dynamics are present, and mitigating subsequent harm is part of the objective.

Our model gives rise to complicated, interesting phenomena related to recommendation safety and harm mitigation. For example, our results (Thms.Â 3.4 and 4.3) suggest that naÃ¯ve approaches to mitigating harm may fail catastrophically. On one hand, explicitly incorporating harm as a penalty in the recommenderâ€™s objective may have no effect in the optimal recommendation policy, if user preference dynamics are ignored. On the other hand, designing optimal recommendations when dynamics are accounted for does not come easy: surprisingly, we prove that data-mining workhorses such as alternating optimization lead to arbitrarily suboptimal recommendations. Overall, our contributions are as follows:

  • â€¢

    We introduce a model that incorporates harm mitigation in a recommenderâ€™s objective. When user preferences are static, we show that top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k recommendations maximize CTR while simultaneously minimizing harm. This finding suggests that to properly mitigate harm, it is necessary to account for user dynamics in the recommenderâ€™s reasoning.

  • â€¢

    To that end, we incorporate the user preference dynamics of attractionÂ (lu2014optimal; krauth2020offline; ge2020understanding; mansoury2020feedback), which explictly model the aforementioned amplification phenomenon. Finding optimal recommendations under these dynamics is a non-convex problem. We prove a negative result: the most natural algorithm, namely, alternating optimization, leads to recommendation policies that are in fact arbitrarily suboptimal.

  • â€¢

    In light of this, we turn our attention to gradient-based algorithms. We propose a tractable method for computing the gradients when preference dynamics are incorporated in the objective. We also evaluate resulting gradient-based recommendation algorithms on a semi-synthetic movie recommendation setting initialized with MovieLens data, where harmful movies are determined by IMDB parental guidelines. We show that our policies are superior at maximizing CTR and mitigating harm over baselines, and perform up to 77% better.

Our model, though simple, is based on the multinomial-logit (MNL) model of choiceÂ (mcfadden1973conditional), which is ubiquitous in recommender systems literatureÂ (danaf2019online; chaptini2005use; yang2011collaborative; kalimeris2021preference). From a technical standpoint, our analysis requires characterizing the stationary point implied by the combination of recommendations with attraction dynamics; we accomplish this by using the Banach fixed point theorem. Having characterized the fixed-point, implementing gradient-based optimization algorithms in our setting poses a significant challenge, as our objective is not expressed in closed form. Nevertheless, we propose a tractable algorithm for computing gradients via the implicit function theorem.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. We discuss related work in SectionÂ 2. We define our model accounting for harm-mitigation, and determine optimal recommendations in the absence of preference dynamics in SectionÂ 3. We present our analysis under user preference dynamics in SectionÂ 4, and our empirical evaluations in SectionÂ 5. We conclude is SectionÂ 6.

2. Related Work

Characterizing Harm. The literature observing and empirically characterizing the harmful impact of algorithmic recommendations is quite extensive. Past works have experimentally observed the existence radicalization pathways (ribeiro2020auditing), polarization and filter bubbles (ledwich2022radical; levin2021dynamics; rossi2021closed), the amplification of extreme content (restrepo2021social; whittaker2021recommender), alignment with human values (gormann2022dangers), and loss of physical and mental well-being (lin2016association; smith2022recommender). Though these studies focus on empirical observations as opposed to the design of harm-mitigating recommendation policies, which is our main goal, they directly motivate our attempt to model the tension between maximizing engagement and reducing exposure to harm.

Multiple Objectives. Multi-objective recommender systems are extensively studiedâ€“see, e.g., the surveys by zheng2022survey and jannach2022multi. Examples include balancing engagement with diversity (vargas2011rank), fairnessÂ (xiao2017fairness), and multi-stakeholder utilityÂ (surer2018multistakeholder). wu2019unified propose alternate optimization and gradient-based approaches, albeit for maximizing utility when making recommendations collectively to a group of users. While not directly considering harm reduction as an objective, suna2021user propose methods to account for user polarization in matrix factorization-based recommender systems. Closer to us, singh2020building use RL to balance an engagement-based reward with a notion of harm termed the â€œhealth riskâ€. We depart from all these works by explicitly modeling user behavior via attraction, as well as by incorporating the possibility that users reject the recommendation and opt instead for organically-selected content. Our model allows for more interpretable decision-making (see, e.g., our discussion around LemmasÂ 4.1 and Thms.Â 3.4â€“4.2) as well as a better understanding of how different parameters impact optimal recommendations and the utility/harm they incur.

Multinomial-Logit Model. For the majority of our analysis, we model user preferences via the multinomial-logit (MNL) modelÂ (mcfadden1973conditional), itself an instance of the more general Plackett-Luce modelÂ (luce1959individual) (see Sec.Â 3). Both are used extensively to model user choices: they are workhorses in the field of econometrics, but have also found numerous applications in computer science, particularly in recommender systems (danaf2019online; chaptini2005use; yang2011collaborative; kalimeris2021preference; oh2019thompson; hazrati2022recommender; fleder2009blockbuster; jiang2014choice; koutra2017pnp). A popular theoretical setting is contextual MNL bandits, (pmlr-v65-agrawal17a; oh2019thompson; oh2021multinomial), in which a static user profile is learned online while top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k recommendations occur; recommendation algorithms in this setting aim to minimize regret w.r.t. the CTR of an algorithm that knows the user profile. Our main departure from this literature is to model a dynamic user profile and incorporate harm. We also depart by studying recommendation policies in â€œsteady-stateâ€; revisiting our results in an online/bandit setting is an interesting and challenging open problem, particularly due to the user preference dynamics (maniu2020bandits; zinkevich2003online; zhang2018dynamic), which are not considered in the aforementioned MNL bandit works.

Preference Dynamics. Models of user preferences are widely used and studied in recommendation literature. Historically, the focus has been on static models (e.g. matrix factorization or topic models), but an emerging line of work models the dynamics of preferences, also termed individual feedback loopsÂ (pagan2023classification). Such models of preference dynamics formalize and illuminate phenomena like political polarizationÂ (leonard2021nonlinear; rossi2021closed) and echo chambersÂ (perra2019modelling; jiang2019degenerate; kalimeris2021preference), in which the long term influence of recommendations plays a crucial role. Many of these works show how feedback loops lead to unintended consequences of traditional recommendation algorithms, critiquing the status quo and proposing alternative algorithms. For example, carroll2021estimating and ashton2022problem argue that recommendations which cause user preferences to shift may be viewed as inappropriate â€œmanipulation,â€ while carroll2021estimating and dean2022preference propose algorithms to avoid this. While some authors propose general purpose algorithms in Markov decision processesÂ (carroll2021estimating; tabibian2020design), most others investigate specific dynamics models connected to particular phenomena of interest. curmei2022towards advocate for a framework mapping between such preference dynamics models in computer science and known psychological effects. We note that the majority of the aforementioned worksÂ (leonard2021nonlinear; jiang2019degenerate; dean2022preference; tabibian2020design; kalimeris2021preference; rossi2021closed; pagan2023classification) study steady-state dynamics of their proposed models, as we do here; however, they do not directly optimize a recommendation policy towards attaining a certain objective in steady state.

Closest to us, lu2014optimalÂ propose a model of user preference dynamics including attraction, aversion, and social influence. Like us, they study optimal recommendations in steady state. However, their underlying recommendation model is based on real-valued feedback in matrix factorization, as opposed to discrete user choice in the MNL model. From a technical standpoint, their dynamics are simpler, and the steady-state profiles can be computed in a closed form (rather than via a fixed point). Moreover, their recommendation design reduces to a quadratic optimization problem in their setting, which they solve via a semi-definite relaxation. Both are technically less challenging than the optimization problem we study here. Furthermore, their focus is on long term user satisfaction rather than avoiding harmful content.

Integrity Checks. Algorithms for detecting and filtering content that is inappropriate or harmful prior to recommendations, i.e. â€œintegrity checks,â€ have been extensively explored by academia and industry alikeÂ (akos2021how; lee2007harmful; arora2023detecting; pierri2023does; zampieri2023offenseval; gillespie2020content). The design of such filtering mechanisms is orthogonal to the question we study. In particular, our starting point is the assumption of perfect filtering, as the recommender never suggests harmful content, which only exists outside the platform: users can find it organically irrespective of recommendations. It is natural to ask if the recommender has a role in mitigating this type of indirect harm, that it cannot directly control. Surprisingly, our work answers affirmatively. If user dynamics are present, then the recommender may cause indirect harm, and its mitigation is non-trivial: naÃ¯ve ways of modeling harm or simple algorithms like alternating optimization may fail catastrophically.

Operationalization. There are many ways to conceive of and operationalize harm. In the context of recommendations, shelby2022sociotechnical and hosseini2023empirical consider representational and allocative harms. Other work considers the meaning of harm from a causal perspective, including loss of utility (beckers2022causal) and counterfactual outcome frameworks (richens2022counterfactual). We limit our scope to harm arising from engagement with problematic content. Our approach relies on modelling the causal mechanisms by which a recommender system may increase the likelihood of harm, in order to reduce it.

3. Modeling Harm-Mitigating Recommendations

We consider a recommender making sequential suggestions to a user. The user can accept the recommendation, by selecting an item in this set, or reject it, by making an â€œorganicâ€ selection of items that exist off-platform; this may lead to a selection of harmful content; we would like to take this into account when recommending items.

We describe here a model of this behavior assuming that user preferences are static, and characterize optimal recommendation policies; as we will see, these differ drastically from recommendations when user preference dynamics are taken into account; we consider these in the next section.

3.1. Recommendation Policies

We consider a universe of nğ‘›nitalic_n items Î©âŠ‚â„dÎ©superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\Omega\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}roman_Î© âŠ‚ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, with |Î©|=nÎ©ğ‘›|\Omega|=n| roman_Î© | = italic_n, where each item is represented by a dğ‘‘ditalic_d-dimensional item profile vâˆˆÎ©ğ‘£Î©v\in\Omegaitalic_v âˆˆ roman_Î© (e.g., explicit features, latent factors). A subset HâŠ‚Î©ğ»Î©H\subset\Omegaitalic_H âŠ‚ roman_Î©, with |H|=hğ»â„|H|=h| italic_H | = italic_h, is known to be harmful. In general, set Î©Î©\Omegaroman_Î© includes both on-platform items, that a recommender may display to users, as well as off-platform items. At each timeslotÂ tğ‘¡titalic_t, a recommender has access to a subset CtâŠ†Î©âˆ–Hsubscriptğ¶ğ‘¡Î©ğ»C_{t}\subseteq\Omega\setminus Hitalic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† roman_Î© âˆ– italic_H of candidate on-platform items for possible recommendation to users. We assume that these candidate sets are sampled in an i.i.d.Â fashion from a collection ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C of (possibly overlapping) subsets of Î©âˆ–HÎ©ğ»\Omega\setminus Hroman_Î© âˆ– italic_H. Having access to this set, the recommender displays to a user a set EtâŠ‚Ctsubscriptğ¸ğ‘¡subscriptğ¶ğ‘¡E_{t}\subset C_{t}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ‚ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; we refer to Etsubscriptğ¸ğ‘¡E_{t}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the recommended set or, simply, the recommendation.

Intuitively, the recommender could be any platform that recommends content, and Î©Î©\Omegaroman_Î© could be all the content on the internet, including harmful content. For example, news could be recommended on a social media platform with links out to external news sites; some â€œfake newsâ€ sites will never be recommended but users could still find them through other means. Note that, by design, the recommender never suggests harmful content, and harmful-content is only found off-platform.

We consider (possibly) randomized recommendation policies: given a candidate set Cğ¶Citalic_C, the recommendation policy is expressed as a distribution over possible sets EâŠ†Cğ¸ğ¶E\subseteq Citalic_E âŠ† italic_C to recommend to the user. Recommendations are constrained. In the bounded cardinality setting, we assume recommended sets Eğ¸Eitalic_E have at most kâˆˆâ„•ğ‘˜â„•k\in\mathbb{N}italic_k âˆˆ blackboard_N items. In the independent sampling setting, we assume that (a) items vâˆˆEğ‘£ğ¸v\in Eitalic_v âˆˆ italic_E are selected independently from Cğ¶Citalic_C and (b) the expected size of recommendations is at most kğ‘˜kitalic_k, i.e., ğ”¼â¢[|E|âˆ£C]â‰¤kğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalğ¸ğ¶ğ‘˜\mathbb{E}[|E|\mid C]\leq kblackboard_E [ | italic_E | âˆ£ italic_C ] â‰¤ italic_k. Independent sampling constrains the size of Eğ¸Eitalic_E only in expectation, but policies can be described with polynomially many parameters (in n,kğ‘›ğ‘˜n,kitalic_n , italic_k), compared with Î˜â¢(2k)Î˜superscript2ğ‘˜\Theta(2^{k})roman_Î˜ ( 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) parameters for bounded cardinality (see also AppendixÂ A).

3.2. User Preferences & Selection Behavior

At each timeslot, the user can accept the recommendation Eğ¸Eitalic_E, by selecting an item in this set, or reject it, by selecting an arbitrary item in Î©.Î©\Omega.roman_Î© . We refer to the former event as a ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºğ™²ğ™»ğ™º\mathtt{CLK}typewriter_CLK event and the latter as an ğ™¾ğšğ™¶ğ™¾ğšğ™¶\mathtt{ORG}typewriter_ORG (for â€œorganic selectionâ€) event. Only ğ™¾ğšğ™¶ğ™¾ğšğ™¶\mathtt{ORG}typewriter_ORG events can lead to a harmful engagement.

We assume that user selections are governed by the Plackett-Luce modelÂ (luce1959individual). In particular, for every vâˆˆÎ©ğ‘£Î©v\in\Omegaitalic_v âˆˆ roman_Î©, there exists a non-negative score svâˆˆâ„+subscriptğ‘ ğ‘£superscriptâ„s_{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{+}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT quantifying a userâ€™s preference toward vğ‘£vitalic_v. Moreover, the probability that a user selects an item among a set of alternatives is proportional to this score. Formally, for a set of items AâŠ†Î©ğ´Î©A\subseteq\Omegaitalic_A âŠ† roman_Î©, let the total score be sAâ‰¡âˆ‘vâˆˆAsvsubscriptğ‘ ğ´subscriptğ‘£ğ´subscriptğ‘ ğ‘£s_{A}\equiv\textstyle\sum_{v\in A}s_{v}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¡ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆˆ italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In our setting, given recommendation Eğ¸Eitalic_E, the user is also faced with an additional alternative of rejecting the recommendation and selecting an item organically. We assume that

3.3. Top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k Recommendations

As items are linked to scores, a simple, intuitive policy is the top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k recommendations policy (karypis2001evaluation) (see also AppendixÂ A). Given Cğ¶Citalic_C and budget kğ‘˜kitalic_k, the policy recommends the kğ‘˜kitalic_k highest-scoring items vâˆˆCğ‘£ğ¶v\in Citalic_v âˆˆ italic_C, w.r.t., scores svsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘£s_{v}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This can be implemented in Oâ¢((|C|+k)â¢logâ¡k)ğ‘‚ğ¶ğ‘˜ğ‘˜O((|C|+k)\log k)italic_O ( ( | italic_C | + italic_k ) roman_log italic_k ) time by traversing the list of scores svsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘£s_{v}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, vâˆˆCğ‘£ğ¶v\in Citalic_v âˆˆ italic_C, and maintaining a sorted list of the highest-scoring items.

3.4. Optimal Recommendations under
Static Preferences

Departing from traditional recommender systems, but assuming static preferences, we would like to select a policy that maximizes CTR while simultaneously minimizing harm; to do so, we wish to solve:

(3a) Maximize::Maximizeabsent\displaystyle\text{Maximize}:Maximize : f0â¢(Ï€)=pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºâ¢(Ï€)âˆ’Î»â¢pğ™·â¢(Ï€)subscriptğ‘“0ğœ‹subscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºğœ‹ğœ†subscriptğ‘ğ™·ğœ‹\displaystyle\quad f_{0}(\pi)=p_{\mathtt{CLK}}(\pi)-\lambda p_{\mathtt{H}}(\pi)italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ ) = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ ) - italic_Î» italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ )
(3b) subj.Â to::subj.Â toabsent\displaystyle\text{subj.~{}to}:subj. to : Ï€âˆˆğ’«,ğœ‹ğ’«\displaystyle\quad\pi\in\mathcal{P},italic_Ï€ âˆˆ caligraphic_P ,

where Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î» is a trade-off parameter, Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ is the recommendation policy specifying [pEâˆ£C]CâŠ†Î©âˆ–H,EâŠ†Csubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘conditionalğ¸ğ¶formulae-sequenceğ¶Î©ğ»ğ¸ğ¶[p_{E\mid C}]_{C\subseteq\Omega\setminus H,E\subseteq C}[ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C âŠ† roman_Î© âˆ– italic_H , italic_E âŠ† italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and

(4) pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™º\displaystyle p_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ğ”¼E,Câ¢[gâ¢(sE)],absentsubscriptğ”¼ğ¸ğ¶delimited-[]ğ‘”subscriptğ‘ ğ¸\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{E,C}[g(s_{E})],= blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_g ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] , pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·\displaystyle p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =(1âˆ’pğ™²ğ™»ğ™º)â¢sHsÎ©,absent1subscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ ğ»subscriptğ‘ Î©\displaystyle=(1-p_{\mathtt{CLK}})\frac{s_{H}}{s_{\Omega}},= ( 1 - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ,

are the probabilities of click (ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºğ™²ğ™»ğ™º\mathtt{CLK}typewriter_CLK) and harm (ğ™·ğ™·\mathtt{H}typewriter_H) events, respectively. The set ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is the set of valid policies, determined either the bounded cardinality or independent sampling constraints with capacity kâˆˆâ„•ğ‘˜â„•k\in\mathbb{N}italic_k âˆˆ blackboard_N (see Eqs.Â (19) andÂ Â (20)â€“(21) in AppendixÂ A). In short, Prob.Â (3) aims to find a valid recommendation policy Ï€âˆˆğ’«ğœ‹ğ’«\pi\in\mathcal{P}italic_Ï€ âˆˆ caligraphic_P that establishes an optimal tradeoff between click-through rate pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and probability of harm pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as determined by parameter Î»â‰¥0ğœ†0\lambda\geq 0italic_Î» â‰¥ 0.

Note that, despite the fact that it never recommends harmful content, the recommender does impact the probability of harm: this is because it can reduce harm by attracting the user to its (non-harmful) recommendations. This has a rather suprising consequence: the top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k recommendations policy is optimal even if the recommender objective includes harm mitigation (i.e., for all Î»>0)\lambda>0)italic_Î» > 0 ):

{thm}

Assume that function g:â„+â†’[0,1]:ğ‘”â†’subscriptâ„01g:\mathbb{R}_{+}\to[0,1]italic_g : blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ [ 0 , 1 ] in Eq.Â (1) is non-decreasing. Then for all Î»â‰¥0ğœ†0\lambda\geq 0italic_Î» â‰¥ 0 the top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k recommendation policy is an optimal solution to Prob.Â (3) under the bounded cardinality setting. If, in addition, function gğ‘”gitalic_g is concave, then top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k recommendation policy is also optimal under the independent sampling setting. The proof can be found in AppendixÂ B. It is straightforward for the bounded cardinality setting; the independent sampling case is somewhat more involved, and requires a submodularity argument. Intuitively, since the recommender never recommends harmful content, maximizing the click-through rate is also harm-minimizing: recommending content likely to be clicked reduces the chance of an organic selection and thus of selecting harmful content. Thm.Â 3.4 is in stark contrast to what happens when the user preferences are affected by recommendations, as we will see in the following section. Moreover, it tells an important cautionary tale: if recommenders treat users as static, recommendations that seemingly account for harm mitigation, by directly including it in the objective, may end up just maximizing click-through rate. This, however, can be catastrophic in terms of the actual harm (and the corresponding objective attained), as we will again see in the next section.

3.5. Multinomial Logit (MNL) Model

We conclude this section by presenting the standard multinomial logit (MNL) model, used extensively to model user choices in recommender systemsÂ (hazrati2022recommender; jiang2014choice; pmlr-v65-agrawal17a; oh2019thompson; oh2021multinomial; kalimeris2021preference). A special case of the Plackett-Luce model, it is a natural generalization of matrix factorization from ratings to choices, and an extension of â€œsoft-maxâ€, allowing for a no-choice alternative (see also AppendixÂ D). Formally, for every vâˆˆÎ©ğ‘£Î©v\in\Omegaitalic_v âˆˆ roman_Î©, the non-negative score svâˆˆâ„+subscriptğ‘ ğ‘£superscriptâ„s_{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{+}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT quantifying a userâ€™s preference toward vğ‘£vitalic_v is

(5) svâ‰¡evâŠ¤â¢u,subscriptğ‘ ğ‘£superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘£topğ‘¢\displaystyle s_{v}\equiv e^{v^{\top}u},italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¡ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

i.e., it is parameterized by both the item profile vâˆˆâ„dğ‘£superscriptâ„ğ‘‘v\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_v âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as well as by a user profile uâˆˆâ„dğ‘¢superscriptâ„ğ‘‘u\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_u âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Moreover, the conditional probability pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºâˆ£Esubscriptğ‘conditionalğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºğ¸p_{\mathtt{CLK}\mid E}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK âˆ£ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is given by:

(6) gâ¢(sE)â‰¡sEsE+c,ğ‘”subscriptğ‘ ğ¸subscriptğ‘ ğ¸subscriptğ‘ ğ¸ğ‘\displaystyle g(s_{E})\equiv\frac{s_{E}}{s_{E}+c}~{},italic_g ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¡ divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c end_ARG ,

where câ‰¥0ğ‘0c\geq 0italic_c â‰¥ 0 is a non-negative constant. The remaining probabilities are given again by the Plackett-Luce model (Eq.Â (2)), with scores determined by Eq.Â (5).

It is easy to confirm that g:â„+â†’[0,1]:ğ‘”â†’subscriptâ„01g:\mathbb{R}_{+}\to[0,1]italic_g : blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ [ 0 , 1 ] is both non-decreasing and concave. Thm.Â 3.4 thus has the following immediate corollary: {cor} If user selections are governed by the MNL model under a static profile uâˆˆâ„dğ‘¢superscriptâ„ğ‘‘u\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_u âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then for all Î»â‰¥0ğœ†0\lambda\geq 0italic_Î» â‰¥ 0 the top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k recommendation policy is an optimal solution to Prob.Â (3) under both the bounded cardinality and independent sampling settings.

4. Harm-Mitigating Recommendations Under Dynamic User Profiles

We turn our attention to what happens when user preferences adapt based on the content that users consume. As we will see, this has drastic implications for harm-mitigating recommendations. A graphical model indicating the evolution of profiles under user dynamics is shown in FigÂ 1.

4.1. User Profile Dynamics

For the remainder of our analysis, we adopt MNL as the model governing user choices. Thus, there exists a user profile uâˆˆâ„dğ‘¢superscriptâ„ğ‘‘u\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_u âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that, jointly with item profiles vâˆˆâ„dğ‘£superscriptâ„ğ‘‘v\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_v âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, determines item scores viaÂ Eq.(5). So far (e.g., in Cor.Â 3.5), we assumed that the user profile is static; we will now depart from this assumption.

Formally, we denote by uâ¢(t)ğ‘¢ğ‘¡u(t)italic_u ( italic_t ) the profile of user at time tâˆˆâ„•ğ‘¡â„•t\in\mathbb{N}italic_t âˆˆ blackboard_N. Let vâ¢(t)âˆˆÎ©ğ‘£ğ‘¡Î©v(t)\in\Omegaitalic_v ( italic_t ) âˆˆ roman_Î© be the item selected and consumed by the user at timeslot tğ‘¡titalic_t. We model the influence of an item with an attraction model (lu2014optimal; krauth2020offline; ge2020understanding; mansoury2020feedback). First, the user is characterised by an inherent profile u0âˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ‘¢0superscriptâ„ğ‘‘u_{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, that captures their predisposition towards content. At time t+1ğ‘¡1t+1italic_t + 1, the profile uâ¢(t+1)ğ‘¢ğ‘¡1u(t+1)italic_u ( italic_t + 1 ) is generated as a convex combination of (a) the inherent profile, (b) the select item vâ¢(t)ğ‘£ğ‘¡v(t)italic_v ( italic_t ), and (c) the current profile uâ¢(t)ğ‘¢ğ‘¡u(t)italic_u ( italic_t ). Formally, starting from some uâ¢(0)âˆˆâ„dğ‘¢0superscriptâ„ğ‘‘u(0)\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_u ( 0 ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have:

(7) uâ¢(t+1)=ğ”¼â¢[Î²â¢u0+Î±vâ¢(t)â¢vâ¢(t)+(1âˆ’Î±vâ¢(t)âˆ’Î²)â¢uâ¢(t)],ğ‘¢ğ‘¡1ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ›½subscriptğ‘¢0subscriptğ›¼ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğ‘£ğ‘¡1subscriptğ›¼ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğ›½ğ‘¢ğ‘¡\displaystyle u(t+1)=\mathbb{E}\left[\beta u_{0}+\alpha_{v(t)}v(t)+(1-\alpha_{% v(t)}-\beta)u(t)\right],italic_u ( italic_t + 1 ) = blackboard_E [ italic_Î² italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_t ) + ( 1 - italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î² ) italic_u ( italic_t ) ] ,

where the randomness is due to the selected item vâ¢(t)ğ‘£ğ‘¡v(t)italic_v ( italic_t ), and Î²âˆˆ[0,1]ğ›½01\beta\in[0,1]italic_Î² âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ], Î±vâˆˆ[0,1âˆ’Î²]subscriptğ›¼ğ‘£01ğ›½\alpha_{v}\in[0,1-\beta]italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 - italic_Î² ], vâˆˆÎ©ğ‘£Î©v\in\Omegaitalic_v âˆˆ roman_Î©, control the the relative importance of the inherent profile and the item, respectively. This is a â€œmean-fieldâ€ or â€œfluidâ€ model (borkar2009stochastic; benaim2006dynamics; benveniste2012adaptive), in which the evolution of the user profile is governed by mean dynamics. It is also an attraction model, as at every timeslot, the user profile â€œnudgesâ€ towards selected object vâ¢(t)ğ‘£ğ‘¡v(t)italic_v ( italic_t ) with a rate Î±vâ¢(t)âˆˆ[0,1]subscriptğ›¼ğ‘£ğ‘¡01\alpha_{v(t)}\in[0,1]italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ]: by Eq.Â (5), this increases the probability that the user will select items similar to the ones it consumed in the past. Note that vâ¢(t)ğ‘£ğ‘¡v(t)italic_v ( italic_t ) is a random variable whose distribution depends on the recommendation policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ and the current user profile uâ¢(t)ğ‘¢ğ‘¡u(t)italic_u ( italic_t ) (see Eq.Â (27)). In general, we allow the â€œattractivenessâ€ to be content dependent. For simplicity of exposition, from here forward, we assume that Î±v=Î±ğ™·,subscriptğ›¼ğ‘£subscriptğ›¼ğ™·\alpha_{v}=\alpha_{\mathtt{H}},italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , if vâˆˆH,ğ‘£ğ»v\in H,italic_v âˆˆ italic_H , and Î±v=Î±ğ™½ğ™·,subscriptğ›¼ğ‘£subscriptğ›¼ğ™½ğ™·\alpha_{v}=\alpha_{\mathtt{NH}},italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , if vâˆ‰H.ğ‘£ğ»v\notin H.italic_v âˆ‰ italic_H .

Stationary Profiles and Steady State Behavior. Given a recommendation policy, we are interested in understanding the steady-state behavior of a user, as described by the limit limtâ†’âˆuâ¢(t)subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡ğ‘¢ğ‘¡\lim_{t\to\infty}u(t)roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_t ). We thus turn our attention to the stationary points of this process, which, as it turns out, we can compute. We define the mean profile drift as:

(8) Î”â¢uâ¢(t)â‰¡uâ¢(t+1)âˆ’uâ¢(t)=ğ”¼Ï€â¢[Î±vâ¢(t)â¢(vâ¢(t)âˆ’uâ¢(t))]+Î²â¢(u0âˆ’uâ¢(t)).Î”ğ‘¢ğ‘¡ğ‘¢ğ‘¡1ğ‘¢ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼ğœ‹delimited-[]subscriptğ›¼ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğ‘¢ğ‘¡ğ›½subscriptğ‘¢0ğ‘¢ğ‘¡\displaystyle\begin{split}\Delta u(t)&\equiv u(t+1)-u(t)\\ &=\mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[\alpha_{v(t)}\left(v(t)-u(t)\right)\right]+\beta\left(% u_{0}-u(t)\right).\end{split}start_ROW start_CELL roman_Î” italic_u ( italic_t ) end_CELL start_CELL â‰¡ italic_u ( italic_t + 1 ) - italic_u ( italic_t ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v ( italic_t ) - italic_u ( italic_t ) ) ] + italic_Î² ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_u ( italic_t ) ) . end_CELL end_ROW

A profile uÂ¯âˆˆâ„dÂ¯ğ‘¢superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\bar{u}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is stationary when Î”â¢uâ¢(t)=0Î”ğ‘¢ğ‘¡0\Delta u(t)=0roman_Î” italic_u ( italic_t ) = 0 for uâ¢(t)=uÂ¯ğ‘¢ğ‘¡Â¯ğ‘¢u(t)=\bar{u}italic_u ( italic_t ) = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG: that is, if the system starts from this profile, it will remain there indefinitely. Note that, if limtâ†’âˆuâ¢(t)subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡ğ‘¢ğ‘¡\lim_{t\to\infty}u(t)roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_t ) exists, it must be a stationary profile.

4.2. Recommendation Objective

We are now ready to revisit our recommendation objective. We denote by Î double-struck-Î \mathbb{\Pi}blackboard_Î  the set of all possible recommendation policies (including invalid ones, not in ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P). Given policy Ï€âˆˆÎ ğœ‹double-struck-Î \pi\in\mathbb{\Pi}italic_Ï€ âˆˆ blackboard_Î , let Ï€â†¦uÂ¯â¢(Ï€)maps-toğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹\pi\mapsto\bar{u}(\pi)italic_Ï€ â†¦ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ) be the map from Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ to the stationary profile uÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¢\bar{u}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG, as defined above (see also Eq.Â (10) below). We consider the following optimization problem:

(9a) Maximize::Maximizeabsent\displaystyle\text{Maximize}:Maximize : fâ¢(Ï€)=pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºâ¢(Ï€,uÂ¯â¢(Ï€))âˆ’Î»â¢pğ™·â¢(Ï€,uÂ¯â¢(Ï€))ğ‘“ğœ‹subscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹ğœ†subscriptğ‘ğ™·ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹\displaystyle~{}~{}f(\pi)=p_{\mathtt{CLK}}(\pi,\bar{u}(\pi))\!-\!\lambda p_{% \mathtt{H}}(\pi,\bar{u}(\pi))italic_f ( italic_Ï€ ) = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ) ) - italic_Î» italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ) )
(9b) subj.Â to::subj.Â toabsent\displaystyle\text{subj.~{}to}:subj. to : Ï€âˆˆğ’«,ğœ‹ğ’«\displaystyle~{}~{}\pi\in\mathcal{P},italic_Ï€ âˆˆ caligraphic_P ,

for some regularization parameter Î»â‰¥0ğœ†0\lambda\geq 0italic_Î» â‰¥ 0. Crucially, both the CTR and the probability of harm are measured at the stationary profile uÂ¯â¢(Ï€)Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹\bar{u}(\pi)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ), our proxy for the steady-state limit of the user dynamics. Note that, even though the recommendation policy never suggests harmful content, recommendations affect user selections, which in turn affect their predisposition towards harmful content.

Solving Prob.Â (9) is quite challenging. Beyond the fact that it is not a convex optimization problem, finding a solution is complicated by the fact that the stationary profiles depend on the recommendation policy Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ via map uÂ¯â¢(Ï€)Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹\bar{u}(\pi)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ), which we cannot express in a closed-form. Thus, we have no direct way of computing it; it is a priori unclear even whether such a stationary profile exists and is unique. One of our contributions is to resolve both of these issues (see Thm.Â 4.2).

Computing uÂ¯â¢(Ï€)Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹\bar{u}(\pi)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ). We now turn our attention to finding the stationary user profile. We fist characterize the stationary profile via a fixed-point equation. Eq.Â (8) implies the following lemma:

Lemma 4.1.

Stationary user profiles uÂ¯âˆˆâ„dÂ¯ğ‘¢superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\bar{u}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfy the following fixed-point equation:

(10) uÂ¯=Fâ¢(Ï€,uÂ¯),Â¯ğ‘¢ğ¹ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢\displaystyle\bar{u}=F(\pi,\bar{u}),overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG = italic_F ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ) ,

where map F:Î Ã—â„d:ğ¹double-struck-Î superscriptâ„ğ‘‘F:\mathbb{\Pi}\times\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_F : blackboard_Î  Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is given by:

(11) Fâ¢(Ï€,u)=Î²â¢u0+Î±ğ™·â¢âˆ‘vâˆˆH[vâ‹…pvâ¢(Ï€,u)]+Î±ğ™½ğ™·â¢âˆ‘vâˆ‰H[vâ‹…pvâ¢(Ï€,u)]Î²+Î±ğ™·â¢pğ™·â¢(Ï€,u)+Î±ğ™½ğ™·â¢pğ™½ğ™·â¢(Ï€,u).ğ¹ğœ‹ğ‘¢ğ›½subscriptğ‘¢0subscriptğ›¼ğ™·subscriptğ‘£ğ»delimited-[]â‹…ğ‘£subscriptğ‘ğ‘£ğœ‹ğ‘¢subscriptğ›¼ğ™½ğ™·subscriptğ‘£ğ»delimited-[]â‹…ğ‘£subscriptğ‘ğ‘£ğœ‹ğ‘¢ğ›½subscriptğ›¼ğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·ğœ‹ğ‘¢subscriptğ›¼ğ™½ğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™½ğ™·ğœ‹ğ‘¢\displaystyle F(\pi,u)=\textstyle\frac{\beta u_{0}+\alpha_{\mathtt{H}}\sum_{v% \in H}[v\cdot p_{v}(\pi,u)]+\alpha_{\mathtt{NH}}\sum_{v\notin H}[v\cdot p_{v}(% \pi,u)]}{\beta+\alpha_{\mathtt{H}}p_{\mathtt{H}}(\pi,u)+\alpha_{\mathtt{NH}}p_% {\mathtt{NH}}(\pi,u)}.italic_F ( italic_Ï€ , italic_u ) = divide start_ARG italic_Î² italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆˆ italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_v â‹… italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ , italic_u ) ] + italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ‰ italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_v â‹… italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ , italic_u ) ] end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î² + italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ , italic_u ) + italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ , italic_u ) end_ARG .

where pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, pğ™½ğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™½ğ™·p_{\mathtt{NH}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, are given by Eq.Â (4), and pvsubscriptğ‘ğ‘£p_{v}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the probability that the user selects item vâˆˆÎ©ğ‘£Î©v\in\Omegaitalic_v âˆˆ roman_Î©.

The proof is in AppendixÂ C. Intuitively, a stationary profile consists of an interpolation between the inherent profile u0subscriptğ‘¢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the â€œaverageâ€ harmful and non-harmful item profiles. The weights of this average are determined by the policy.

Next, we turn to the question of finding a stationary profile which satisfies the fixed point equation. In particular, we establish conditions under which map Fğ¹Fitalic_F in Eq.Â (11) is a contraction:

{thm}

Let âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥\|\cdot\|âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ denote the Euclidean norm in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. If

(12) â€–vâ€–<16â¢(â€–u0â€–2+12â¢Î±ğ™½ğ™·+Î²5â¢nâ¢dâ¢Î±Hâˆ’â€–u0â€–),normğ‘£16superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘¢0212subscriptğ›¼ğ™½ğ™·ğ›½5ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptğ›¼ğ»normsubscriptğ‘¢0\displaystyle\|v\|<\frac{1}{6}\big{(}\sqrt{\textstyle\|u_{0}\|^{2}+12\frac{% \alpha_{\mathtt{NH}}+\beta}{5nd\alpha_{H}}}-\|u_{0}\|\big{)},âˆ¥ italic_v âˆ¥ < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 6 end_ARG ( square-root start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 12 divide start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î² end_ARG start_ARG 5 italic_n italic_d italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG - âˆ¥ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ ) ,

for all vâˆˆÎ©ğ‘£Î©v\in\Omegaitalic_v âˆˆ roman_Î©, then F:Î Ã—â„d:ğ¹double-struck-Î superscriptâ„ğ‘‘F:\mathbb{\Pi}\times\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_F : blackboard_Î  Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT given by Eq.Â (10) is a contraction w.r.t.Â âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥\|\cdot\|âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ uniformly on all distributions Ï€âˆˆÎ ğœ‹double-struck-Î \pi\in\mathbb{\Pi}italic_Ï€ âˆˆ blackboard_Î . That is, for all distributions Ï€âˆˆÎ ğœ‹double-struck-Î \pi\in\mathbb{\Pi}italic_Ï€ âˆˆ blackboard_Î  (not necessarily in ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P), and all u,uâ€²âˆˆâ„dğ‘¢superscriptğ‘¢â€²superscriptâ„ğ‘‘u,u^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_u , italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, â€–Fâ¢(Ï€,u)âˆ’Fâ¢(Ï€,uâ€²)â€–â‰¤Lâ¢â€–uâˆ’uâ€²â€–,normğ¹ğœ‹ğ‘¢ğ¹ğœ‹superscriptğ‘¢â€²ğ¿normğ‘¢superscriptğ‘¢â€²\|F(\pi,u)-F(\pi,u^{\prime})\|\leq L\|u-u^{\prime}\|,âˆ¥ italic_F ( italic_Ï€ , italic_u ) - italic_F ( italic_Ï€ , italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_L âˆ¥ italic_u - italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ , for some L<1ğ¿1L<1italic_L < 1 that does not depend on Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€. We prove this in AppendixÂ E. Thm.Â 4.2 along with the Banach fixed-point theoremÂ (banach1922operations) imply that a stationary profile exists and is unique when Eq.Â (12) holds. Most importantly, it can be found by the following iterative process: starting from any uÂ¯0âˆˆâ„dsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘¢0superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\bar{u}^{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the iterations

(13) uÂ¯â„“+1=Fâ¢(Ï€,uÂ¯â„“),â„“âˆˆâ„•,formulae-sequencesuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘¢â„“1ğ¹ğœ‹superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¢â„“â„“â„•\displaystyle\bar{u}^{\ell+1}=F(\pi,\bar{u}^{\ell}),\quad\ell\in\mathbb{N},overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_F ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , roman_â„“ âˆˆ blackboard_N ,

are guaranteed to converge to the unique fixed-point uÂ¯âˆ—superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¢\bar{u}^{*}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of Eq.Â (10). Convergence happens exponentially fast (see Appendix.Â E).

Note that Eq.Â (12) holds w.l.o.g.: multiplying every vâˆˆÎ©ğ‘£Î©v\in\Omegaitalic_v âˆˆ roman_Î© with a constant Ï„<1ğœ1\tau<1italic_Ï„ < 1 and u0subscriptğ‘¢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with 1/Ï„1ğœ1/\tau1 / italic_Ï„ yields exactly the same scores in Eq.Â (5). Hence, inherent user profiles and item profiles learned from data (e.g., user-item clicks), can be rescaled so that Eq.Â (12) holds.

4.3. Alternating Optimization

Armed with Thm.Â 4.2, we turn our attention to algorithms for solving the (non-convex) Prob.Â (9) in its general form. A simple approach is via an alternating optimization/EM-like algorithm. In particular, one could start from, e.g., the userâ€™s initial profile u0subscriptğ‘¢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and iterate as follows, for â„“âˆˆâ„•â„“â„•\ell\in\mathbb{N}roman_â„“ âˆˆ blackboard_N:

(14a) Ï€â„“+1superscriptğœ‹â„“1\displaystyle\pi^{\ell+1}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =argâ¡maxÏ€âˆˆğ’«(pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºâ¢(Ï€,uâ„“)âˆ’Î»â¢pğ™·â¢(Ï€,uâ„“)),absentsubscriptğœ‹ğ’«subscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºğœ‹superscriptğ‘¢â„“ğœ†subscriptğ‘ğ™·ğœ‹superscriptğ‘¢â„“\displaystyle=\textstyle\mathop{\arg\,\max}_{\pi\in\mathcal{P}}\left(p_{% \mathtt{CLK}}(\pi,u^{\ell})-\lambda p_{\mathtt{H}}(\pi,u^{\ell})\right),= start_BIGOP roman_arg roman_max end_BIGOP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ âˆˆ caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ , italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_Î» italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ , italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ,
(14b) uâ„“+1superscriptğ‘¢â„“1\displaystyle u^{\ell+1}italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =uÂ¯â¢(Ï€â„“).absentÂ¯ğ‘¢superscriptğœ‹â„“\displaystyle=\bar{u}(\pi^{\ell}).= overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

In step (14a), given uâ„“superscriptğ‘¢â„“u^{\ell}italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the optimal Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ is determined by the top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k policy (by Thm.Â 3.4). In step (14b), given Ï€â„“superscriptğœ‹â„“\pi^{\ell}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the map uÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¢\bar{u}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG is computed via the iterative algorithm in Eq.Â (13). The algorithm thus alternates between finding an optimal recommendation policy and the corresponding stationary profile. Unfortunately, this approach fails: {thm} The alternating optimization steps in AlgorithmÂ (14) can be arbitrarily suboptimal: for every M>0ğ‘€0M>0italic_M > 0, we can construct an instance of Prob.Â (9) with optimal solution Ï€âˆ—superscriptğœ‹\pi^{*}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for which the solution Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ produced by AlgorithmÂ (14) satisfies fâ¢(Ï€âˆ—)âˆ’fâ¢(Ï€)>Mğ‘“superscriptğœ‹ğ‘“ğœ‹ğ‘€f(\pi^{*})-f(\pi)>Mitalic_f ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f ( italic_Ï€ ) > italic_M. The proof is in AppendixÂ F. On a high level, even though Alg.Â (14) produces a different solution than the top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k policy with profile u0subscriptğ‘¢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as it takes into account the steady state profile, Thm.Â 3.4 implies that this trajectory is independent of Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î». This leads to arbitrarily suboptimal decisions when Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î» is high, and minimizing the probability of harm is paramount.

4.4. Gradient-Based Algorithms

The suboptimality of alternating optimization highlights the importance of understanding the evolution Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ and uÂ¯â¢(Ï€)Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹\bar{u}(\pi)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ) jointly. This can indeed be accomplished via a continuous optimization algorithm like projected gradient ascent (PGA)Â (bertsekas1997nonlinear). The constraint set in both the bounded cardinality and the independent sampling settings is a convex polytope. Applying first-order methods to solve this requires computing the gradient of the objectiveÂ (9a). However, this poses a challenge exactly because we cannot describe uÂ¯â¢(â‹…)Â¯ğ‘¢â‹…\bar{u}(\cdot)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( â‹… ) in closed form. Nevertheless, we show that âˆ‡uÂ¯â¢(â‹…)âˆ‡Â¯ğ‘¢â‹…\nabla\bar{u}(\cdot)âˆ‡ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( â‹… ) and, subsequently âˆ‡fâ¢(â‹…)âˆ‡ğ‘“â‹…\nabla f(\cdot)âˆ‡ italic_f ( â‹… ), can be computed using the implicit function theoremÂ (folland2001advanced; blondel2022efficient). We briefly review PGA for the bounded cardinality setting below, and provide implementation details for PGA in both constraint settings in the supplement. Nevertheless, we stress that these gradients can be used in other standard solvers; we demonstrate this in our experiments, where we use the (more powerful) SLSQP solver (kraft1988software) instead.

Projected Gradient Ascent. PGA starts from a feasible policy Ï€0âˆˆğ’«subscriptğœ‹0ğ’«\pi_{0}\in\mathcal{P}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_P and proceeds iteratively via:

(15) Ï€â„“+1=ğš™ğš›ğš˜ğš“ğ’«â¢(Ï€â„“+Î³â„“â¢âˆ‡Ï€fâ¢(Ï€â„“,uÂ¯â¢(Ï€â„“))),â„“âˆˆâ„•,formulae-sequencesubscriptğœ‹â„“1subscriptğš™ğš›ğš˜ğš“ğ’«subscriptğœ‹â„“subscriptğ›¾â„“subscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹ğ‘“superscriptğœ‹â„“Â¯ğ‘¢superscriptğœ‹â„“â„“â„•\displaystyle\pi_{\ell+1}=\mathtt{proj}_{\mathcal{P}}\left(\pi_{\ell}+\gamma_{% \ell}\nabla_{\pi}f(\pi^{\ell},\bar{u}(\pi^{\ell}))\right),~{}~{}\ell\in\mathbb% {N},italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = typewriter_proj start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ) , roman_â„“ âˆˆ blackboard_N ,

where ğš™ğš›ğš˜ğš“ğ’«â¢(Ï€â€²)=argâ¡minÏ€âˆˆğ’«â€–Ï€âˆ’Ï€â€²â€–22subscriptğš™ğš›ğš˜ğš“ğ’«superscriptğœ‹â€²subscriptğœ‹ğ’«superscriptsubscriptnormğœ‹superscriptğœ‹â€²22{\mathtt{proj}_{\mathcal{P}}}(\pi^{\prime})=\mathop{\arg\,\min}_{\pi\in% \mathcal{P}}\|\pi-\pi^{\prime}\|_{2}^{2}typewriter_proj start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = start_BIGOP roman_arg roman_min end_BIGOP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ âˆˆ caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Ï€ - italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the projection to ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. As ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is a union of simplices (see AppendixÂ A), ğš™ğš›ğš˜ğš“ğ’«subscriptğš™ğš›ğš˜ğš“ğ’«\mathtt{proj}_{\mathcal{P}}typewriter_proj start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has efficient implementations (see, e.g., (michelot1986finite)).

Computing the Gradient for the Bounded Cardinality Setting. Let mâ‰¡âˆ‘Câˆˆğ’|ğ’ŸC|=âˆ‘Câˆˆğ’(|C|k)ğ‘šsubscriptğ¶ğ’subscriptğ’Ÿğ¶subscriptğ¶ğ’binomialğ¶ğ‘˜m\equiv\sum_{C\in\mathcal{C}}|\mathcal{D}_{C}|=\sum_{C\in\mathcal{C}}{|C|% \choose k}italic_m â‰¡ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( binomial start_ARG | italic_C | end_ARG start_ARG italic_k end_ARG ) be the number of parameters in Ï€âˆˆğ’«ğœ‹ğ’«\pi\in\mathcal{P}italic_Ï€ âˆˆ caligraphic_P. By the chain rule, we have:

(16) âˆ‡Ï€fâ¢(Ï€,uÂ¯â¢(Ï€))=âˆ‡Ï€ğ’°â¢(Ï€,uÂ¯)+[âˆ‡Ï€uÂ¯â¢(Ï€)]âŠ¤â¢âˆ‡uğ’°â¢(Ï€,u),subscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹ğ‘“ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹subscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹ğ’°ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢superscriptdelimited-[]subscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹topsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¢ğ’°ğœ‹ğ‘¢\displaystyle\nabla_{\pi}f(\pi,\bar{u}(\pi))\!=\!\nabla_{\pi}\mathcal{U}(\pi,% \!\bar{u})\!+\!\left[\nabla_{\pi}\bar{u}(\pi)\right]^{\top}\!\!\nabla_{u}% \mathcal{U}(\pi,\!u),\!\!âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ) ) = âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_U ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ) + [ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_U ( italic_Ï€ , italic_u ) ,

where ğ’°â¢(Ï€,u)â‰¡pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºâ¢(Ï€,u)âˆ’Î»â¢pğ™·â¢(Ï€,u),ğ’°ğœ‹ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºğœ‹ğ‘¢ğœ†subscriptğ‘ğ™·ğœ‹ğ‘¢\mathcal{U}(\pi,u)\equiv p_{\mathtt{CLK}}(\pi,u)-\lambda p_{\mathtt{H}}(\pi,u),caligraphic_U ( italic_Ï€ , italic_u ) â‰¡ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ , italic_u ) - italic_Î» italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ , italic_u ) , and âˆ‡Ï€ğ’°â¢(Ï€,uÂ¯)âˆˆâ„msubscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹ğ’°ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢superscriptâ„ğ‘š\nabla_{\pi}\mathcal{U}(\pi,\bar{u})\in\mathbb{R}^{m}âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_U ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, âˆ‡uğ’°â¢(Ï€,uÂ¯)âˆˆâ„dsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¢ğ’°ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\nabla_{u}\mathcal{U}(\pi,\bar{u})\in\mathbb{R}^{d}âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_U ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are the gradients of ğ’°ğ’°\mathcal{U}caligraphic_U w.r.t.Â its first and second arguments, respectively, evaluated at inputs Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ and uÂ¯=uÂ¯â¢(Ï€)Â¯ğ‘¢Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹\bar{u}=\bar{u}(\pi)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ). As we have closed-form, differentiable expressions for pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and pğ™½ğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™½ğ™·p_{\mathtt{NH}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, these two gradients can be computed via standard means, while uÂ¯=uÂ¯â¢(Ï€)Â¯ğ‘¢Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹\bar{u}=\bar{u}(\pi)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ) can be computed via Eq.Â (13).

We thus turn our attention to computing âˆ‡Ï€uÂ¯â¢(Ï€)âˆˆâ„dÃ—msubscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘š\nabla_{\pi}\bar{u}(\pi)\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times m}âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d Ã— italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i.e., the Jacobian of map uÂ¯â¢(â‹…)Â¯ğ‘¢â‹…\bar{u}(\cdot)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( â‹… ) w.r.t.Â Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€, which we cannot express in closed form. Observe that Ï€âˆˆ[0,1]mğœ‹superscript01ğ‘š\pi\in[0,1]^{m}italic_Ï€ âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, while uÂ¯âˆˆâ„dÂ¯ğ‘¢superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\bar{u}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Eq.Â (10) implies that Fâ¢(Ï€,uÂ¯)âˆ’uÂ¯=0,ğ¹ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢Â¯ğ‘¢0F(\pi,\bar{u})-\bar{u}=0,italic_F ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ) - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG = 0 , where Fğ¹Fitalic_F is given by (11). This is a system of dğ‘‘ditalic_d non-linear equations, involving both Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ and uÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¢\bar{u}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG as unknowns. Hence, by the implicit function theorem (folland2001advanced), the Jacobian âˆ‡Ï€uÂ¯â¢(Ï€)subscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹\nabla_{\pi}\bar{u}(\pi)âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ), can be computed via:

(17) âˆ‡Ï€uÂ¯â¢(Ï€)=âˆ’(âˆ‡uFâ¢(Ï€,uÂ¯)âˆ’IdÃ—d)âˆ’1â‹…âˆ‡Ï€Fâ¢(Ï€,uÂ¯),subscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹â‹…superscriptsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¢ğ¹ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢subscriptğ¼ğ‘‘ğ‘‘1subscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹ğ¹ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢\displaystyle\nabla_{\pi}\bar{u}(\pi)=-\left(\nabla_{u}F(\pi,\bar{u})-I_{d% \times d}\right)^{-1}\cdot\nabla_{\pi}F(\pi,\bar{u}),âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ) = - ( âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ) - italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ) ,

where âˆ‡Ï€Fâ¢(Ï€,uÂ¯)âˆˆâ„dÃ—msubscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹ğ¹ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘š\nabla_{\pi}F(\pi,\bar{u})\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times m}âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d Ã— italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, âˆ‡uFâ¢(Ï€,uÂ¯)âˆˆâ„dÃ—dsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¢ğ¹ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘‘\nabla_{u}F(\pi,\bar{u})\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are the Jacobians of map Fğ¹Fitalic_F w.r.t.Â its two arguments, evaluated again at Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ and uÂ¯=uÂ¯â¢(Ï€)Â¯ğ‘¢Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹\bar{u}=\bar{u}(\pi)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ). As Fğ¹Fitalic_F is a closed-form, differentiable function, constituent matrices in the r.h.s. can be computed by standard techniques, and âˆ‡Ï€uÂ¯â¢(Ï€)subscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹\nabla_{\pi}\bar{u}(\pi)âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ) can be obtained by solving a linear system (to avoid matrix inversion). Additional details, along with ways of computing the gradient for the independent sampling setting, can be found in AppendixÂ G.

Computational Complexity and Tractability. For the bounded cardinality setting, gradient computations via Eqs.Â (16)â€“(17) involve (a) linear algebra operations (matrix multiplications, solving linear systems) and (b) computing the stationary point uÂ¯â¢(Ï€)Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹\bar{u}(\pi)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ). The former can be done in polynomial time in constituent matrix dimensions mğ‘šmitalic_m and dğ‘‘ditalic_d. The latter can be computed via the iterations in Eq.Â (13): each iteration is again polynomial in mğ‘šmitalic_m and dğ‘‘ditalic_d, and convergence is exponentially fast (see also the discussion below Thm.Â 4.2). Having computed the gradient, using Michelotâ€™s algorithmÂ (michelot1986finite), the projection in Eq.Â (15) is Oâ¢(mâ¢logâ¡m)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ‘šO(m\log m)italic_O ( italic_m roman_log italic_m ), while the remaining operations in PGA steps (15) are linear in mğ‘šmitalic_m. Finally, all of the above statements extend to the independent sampling setting, with mğ‘šmitalic_m replaced by mâ€²â‰¡âˆ‘Câˆˆğ’|C|superscriptğ‘šâ€²subscriptğ¶ğ’ğ¶m^{\prime}\equiv\sum_{C\in\mathcal{C}}|C|italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¡ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_C | (see AppendicesÂ A andÂ G).

We stress that bounded cardinality setting operations are efficient only if mğ‘šmitalic_m is polynomial in nğ‘›nitalic_n; this is the case only when kğ‘˜kitalic_k is fixed (e.g., when k=3ğ‘˜3k=3italic_k = 3), and the recommender only recommends a few items to the user. In contrast, as mâ€²=âˆ‘Câˆˆğ’|C|superscriptğ‘šâ€²subscriptğ¶ğ’ğ¶m^{\prime}=\sum_{C\in\mathcal{C}}|C|italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_C |, the independent sampling setting can be polynomial in nğ‘›nitalic_n for all kğ‘˜kitalic_k: for example, if ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C is a partition of Î©âˆ–HÎ©ğ»\Omega\setminus Hroman_Î© âˆ– italic_H, then mâ€²=nâˆ’hsuperscriptğ‘šâ€²ğ‘›â„m^{\prime}=n-hitalic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_n - italic_h, which does not depend on kğ‘˜kitalic_k.

5. Experiments

5.1. Experimental Setup

Dataset. We use the MovieLens25m dataset to extract movie and item profiles and the IMDB parental guideline ratingsÂ (Hay2023; IMDBParent) to determine our definition of harmful movies. The IMDB parental guideline ratings comprise 5 categories: (1) Sex & Nudity, (2) Violence & Gore, (3) Profanity, (4) Alcohol, Drugs, & Smoking, and (5) Frightening & Intense Scenes. For these experiments, we consider a movie harmful if it is â€œSevereâ€â€”the worst parental ratingâ€”in any of these categories. We join the MovieLens25m dataset with the IMDB data set via the IMDB movie identifiers, and then create 5 sub-datasets by filtering containing movies from 5 categories: â€œActionâ€, â€œAdventureâ€, â€œComedyâ€, â€œFantasyâ€, and â€œSci-Fiâ€. We restrict each dataset to the 100 movies with the most ratings and 100 users, with user and movie profiles of dimension d=12ğ‘‘12d=12italic_d = 12 constructed via matrix factorization. Learned profiles play the role of u0subscriptğ‘¢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and vğ‘£vitalic_v in our experiments. Full details on the this pre-processing pipeline, including hyperparameters, can be found in AppendixÂ H. We make our code publicly available.111https://github.com/jerry-chee/HarmMitigation

Model Parameters. We use MF user profiles as u0subscriptğ‘¢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (inherent profiles), and item profiles vğ‘£vitalic_v as extracted from the above matrix factorization process. We use these values into our model to compute the steady-state behavior of each of different policies, but also simulate the evolution of the user profiles under these policies. Unless otherwise noted, we use Î±ğ™·=0.25subscriptğ›¼ğ™·0.25\alpha_{\mathtt{H}}=0.25italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.25, ağ™½ğ™·=0.5subscriptğ‘ğ™½ğ™·0.5a_{\mathtt{NH}}=0.5italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.5, Î²=0.15ğ›½0.15\beta=0.15italic_Î² = 0.15, and Î»=100ğœ†100\lambda=100italic_Î» = 100 (though we also explore the impact of these parameters). Unless otherwise noted, we use k=1ğ‘˜1k=1italic_k = 1 under the bounded cardinality setting for most experiments, exploring the impact of kğ‘˜kitalic_k on recommendations separately under the independent sampling setting. We calibrate cğ‘citalic_c in function gğ‘”gitalic_g (Eq.Â (33)) in the range [1,20]120[1,20][ 1 , 20 ] to balance the steady-state mean pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPTÂ ( Eq.(4)) under a benchmark recommendation policy (the uniform recommendation policy, described below). The full set of values of cğ‘citalic_c per dataset, as well as the corresponding justification for these choices, is given in AppendixÂ H.

As we use profiles learned from data, rather than user ratings directly, our experiments are semi-synthetic. Note that going beyond semi-synthetic experiments poses several challenges which we share with the broader recommender system literature (e.g., oh2019thompson; oh2021multinomial): assessing the performance of different policies would require knowing how a user would react to alternatives they have not seen, which we cannot extract from offline datasets.

Algorithms. We implement the following algorithms: Gradient-Based Algorithm (Grad) is the SLSQP implementation of SciPyÂ (2020SciPy-NMeth), for both the bounded cardinality and the independent sampling setting, using our gradient computation approach as described in Sec.Â 4 and Appendix.Â G; Alternating Optimization (Alt) is is the (suboptimal) alternating optimization algorithm in Eq.Â (14); Static Profile Optimization (U0) is the optimal policy under static profile u0subscriptğ‘¢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as determined by Thm.Â 3.4; finally, Uniform Recommendations (Unif) is the policy that selects the recommended set u.a.r. Additional implementation details, including convergence tolerance criteria, are in AppendixÂ H. We stress here that, as Prob.Â (9) is non-convex, it is not a priori clear that Grad reaches a globally optimal policy.

Metrics. We report the recommendation objectiveÂ (Eq.Â (9)), as well as its constituent pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We also measure â€–limtâ†’âˆuâ¢(t)âˆ’uÂ¯â€–normsubscriptâ†’ğ‘¡ğ‘¢ğ‘¡Â¯ğ‘¢\|\lim_{t\to\infty}u(t)-\bar{u}\|âˆ¥ roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u ( italic_t ) - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG âˆ¥Â (Eq.Â (7),(10)), the distance of the user profile dynamics as time evolves under a given policy and the corresponding fixed point.

5.2. Results

Recommendation Policy Comparison. TableÂ 2 reports our key metrics over the 5 movie genre data sets, averaged across the 100 users in the dataset. Across all genre datasets, Grad attains superior recommendation objective values, while the improvement over uniform is as much as 77% (for Sci-Fi). Surprisingly, our policy does not need to sacrifice pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to attain low pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in comparison to other policies; it is superior in both terms. This is because it recommends an item (a) users become more likely to click, in steady state, and (b) is distinct enough from harmful content, so that pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT remains low.

We note that, even though we report standard deviations, Grad dominates other policies in terms of the objective also on a per user basis: this is evident in Fig.Â 2, where we report also the PDFs of the difference of objectives from the one attained by Grad (additional genres are in the appendix). In Fig.Â 3, we visualize the which movies each policy recommends for two users in the Action and Adventure genres. We display each vector vğ‘£vitalic_v with respect to their inner product with the mean non-harmful and harmful vector. We observe that the gradient-based policy is more concentrated towards the right, i.e., on movies which have high inner product with the average non-harmful vector. Similar observations hold for remaining genres (see Fig.Â 7 in AppendixÂ H).

Understanding the Effect of Model Parameters. We plot the effect of modifying Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î», Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î², and cğ‘citalic_c on the objective attained by different policies for the Action genre in Fig.Â 4; additional genres, as well as the effect these parameters have on pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, are shown in Figs.Â 11â€“13 in AppendixÂ H. Increasing any parameter decreases the objective attained by every policy, which is intuitive. We also observe that increasing Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î» naturally increases the performance gap of the Grad policy. Increasing Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² has the opposite effect, as it limits the ability of all policies to impact a userâ€™s profile. Parameter cğ‘citalic_c also increases the improvement of Grad over other policies as, the larger cğ‘citalic_c is, the less likely the recommendation is to be accepted, and the more important it becomes to minimize harm.

In Fig.Â 5, we also plot the impact of the ratio Î±ğ™·/Î±ğ™½ğ™·subscriptğ›¼ğ™·subscriptğ›¼ğ™½ğ™·\alpha_{\mathtt{H}}/\alpha_{\mathtt{NH}}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on the objective attained by different policies for the Action and Adventure genres. Increasing the ratio decreases the objective attained by every policy as well as the gap from Grad, as policies have less leeway in minimizing harm. Similar observations hold for other genres (see Figs.Â 14â€“16 in AppendixÂ H).

Convergence. For all datasets, policies, and users in the experiments reported in TableÂ 2, we also compute the user profile dynamics in Eq.Â (7). In all experiments, they converge to the corresponding stationary user profile in LemmaÂ 4.1, within a 10âˆ’3superscript10310^{-3}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT tolerance; see TableÂ 3 for per genre tolerances.

Increasing Recommendation Size under the Independent Sampling Setting. Next, we study the scalability of our algorithms by increasing the recommendation size kğ‘˜kitalic_k, under the independent sampling setting. In Fig.Â 6 we plot the impact of kğ‘˜kitalic_k on the objective for the Action genre, under two different scenarios: in one, we vary cğ‘citalic_c along with kğ‘˜kitalic_k, while in the other we keep it fixed. Intuitively, as kğ‘˜kitalic_k increases, pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT converges to one, and pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT collapses to zero. Thus, to better understand the performance of different policies as kğ‘˜kitalic_k increases we make the optimization â€œharderâ€ as we increase kğ‘˜kitalic_k. To accomplish this, recall from Sec.Â 3 the total score of a recommendes set EâŠ†Î©ğ¸Î©E\subseteq\Omegaitalic_E âŠ† roman_Î© is SEâ‰¡âˆ‘vâˆˆEsvsubscriptğ‘†ğ¸subscriptğ‘£ğ¸subscriptğ‘ ğ‘£S_{E}\equiv\sum_{v\in E}s_{v}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¡ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆˆ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and that the conditional probability pğ™²ğ™»ğ™º|E=gâ¢(sE)â‰¡sE/(sE+c)subscriptğ‘conditionalğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºğ¸ğ‘”subscriptğ‘ ğ¸subscriptğ‘ ğ¸subscriptğ‘ ğ¸ğ‘p_{\mathtt{CLK}|E}=g(s_{E})\equiv s_{E}/(s_{E}+c)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK | italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_g ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¡ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c ). Assuming SEsubscriptğ‘†ğ¸S_{E}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT grows proportionally with kğ‘˜kitalic_k, setting cğ‘citalic_c to also grow proportionally with kğ‘˜kitalic_k keeps pğ™²ğ™»ğ™º|Esubscriptğ‘conditionalğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºğ¸p_{\mathtt{CLK}|E}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK | italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT relatively constant, allowing us to better understand how increasing kğ‘˜kitalic_k effects harm. In Fig.Â 6(a), when cğ‘citalic_c is fixed, we see that all policies improve (as expected) w.r.t. the overal objective, with Grad dominating other policies. In Fig.Â 6(b), when cğ‘citalic_c is proportional to kğ‘˜kitalic_k, the problem becomes harder and the objective decreases, with Grad still being dominant; this is confirmed when observing the impact on pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, reported in AppendixÂ H.

6. Conclusions

Overall, our goal is to gain a better understanding of real-world phenomena through a simplified but insightful model. We study a model in which the likelihood of consuming harmful content, though never directly the result of a recommendation, can nonetheless be influenced by a recommendation policy through its impact on user preferences. The notion of harm that we study is simple: content is known to be either harmful or non-harmful, and recommenders will never recommend harmful content. Despite this, considerable complexity arises from the user behavior model which is influenced on both short (via clicks) and long (via interests) timescales by the choices of the recommender. We develop algorithms for designing recommenders which simultaneously maximize a CTR objective while minimizing the likelihood of harm and verify their performance on a setting initialized with real movie rating data. We present compelling evidence that a user pathway to harm should be accounted for; this is missing in both literature and practice. We rigorously substantiate that solely maximizing the click-through-rate may come at the cost of shifting user preferences towards harm.

Our focus on the long term impacts of recommendations leads to conceptions of harm that are both mathematically challenging and conceptually rich. Many opportunities for future work remain in the setting that we study, for example: under what conditions are user profiles guaranteed to converge to a fixed point? Is it possible to make guarantees about tractable algorithms for optimizing our non-convex objective? Many open questions arise from relaxing our assumptions, like: what if users interests evolve according to something other than attraction (e.g. repulsionÂ (lu2014optimal), biased assimilationÂ (dean2022preference)). What if user and item profiles are not directly observed, and must be learned from data? Finally, we hope that our perspective, centered on the dynamics of users, can contribute to the rich literature on harms caused by algorithmic systems and inspire effective methods for mitigation.

Acknowledgements.
This work was partly funded by NSF CCF-2312774, NSF OAC-2311521, and NSF DGE-1922551.

Appendix A Recommendation Policies
