We refer to the conditional probabilities Ï€=[pEâˆ£C]CâŠ†Î©âˆ–H,EâŠ†Cğœ‹subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘conditionalğ¸ğ¶formulae-sequenceğ¶Î©ğ»ğ¸ğ¶\pi=[p_{E\mid C}]_{C\subseteq\Omega\setminus H,E\subseteq C}italic_Ï€ = [ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C âŠ† roman_Î© âˆ– italic_H , italic_E âŠ† italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the recommendation policy, and assume that, conditioned on Cğ¶Citalic_C, Eğ¸Eitalic_E is sampled from Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ independently at each timeslot. We denote by Î double-struck-Î \mathbb{\Pi}blackboard_Î  the set of all possible recommendation policies. We denote by ğ’«âŠ‚Î ğ’«double-struck-Î \mathcal{P}\subset\mathbb{\Pi}caligraphic_P âŠ‚ blackboard_Î  the set of valid policies, that satisfy desired constraints; we describe several examples below.

Bounded Cardinality. In this setting, only sets Eğ¸Eitalic_E of cardinality |E|â‰¤kğ¸ğ‘˜|E|\leq k| italic_E | â‰¤ italic_k may be recommended, for some kâˆˆâ„•ğ‘˜â„•k\in\mathbb{N}italic_k âˆˆ blackboard_N. Formally, given Câˆˆğ’ğ¶ğ’C\in\mathcal{C}italic_C âˆˆ caligraphic_C, let

(18) ğ’ŸC={EâŠ†C:|E|â‰¤k},subscriptğ’Ÿğ¶conditional-setğ¸ğ¶ğ¸ğ‘˜\displaystyle\mathcal{D}_{C}=\{E\subseteq C:|E|\leq k\},caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_E âŠ† italic_C : | italic_E | â‰¤ italic_k } ,

be the set of subsets of cardinality kğ‘˜kitalic_k. Then, a valid recommendation policy is a probability distribution over these sets, i.e.:

(19) ğ’«={Ï€âˆˆÎ :âˆ‘Eâˆˆğ’ŸCpEâˆ£C=1,Â for allâ¢Câˆˆğ’}.ğ’«conditional-setğœ‹double-struck-Î formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¸subscriptğ’Ÿğ¶subscriptğ‘conditionalğ¸ğ¶1Â for allğ¶ğ’\displaystyle\begin{split}\mathcal{P}&=\big{\{}\pi\in\mathbb{\Pi}:\textstyle% \sum_{E\in\mathcal{D}_{C}}p_{E\mid C}=1,\text{ for all}~{}C\in\mathcal{C}\big{% \}}.\end{split}start_ROW start_CELL caligraphic_P end_CELL start_CELL = { italic_Ï€ âˆˆ blackboard_Î  : âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 , for all italic_C âˆˆ caligraphic_C } . end_CELL end_ROW

Independent Sampling. In this setting, we assume that, given the candidate set Câˆˆğ’ğ¶ğ’C\in\mathcal{C}italic_C âˆˆ caligraphic_C, the recommended items are selected independently with a fixed probability. Formally, the probability that the recommended set is Eğ¸Eitalic_E is given by:

(20) pEâˆ£C=âˆvâˆˆEÏvâˆ£Câ¢âˆvâ€²âˆ‰E(1âˆ’Ïvâ€²âˆ£C),for allâ¢EâŠ†C,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘conditionalğ¸ğ¶subscriptproductğ‘£ğ¸subscriptğœŒconditionalğ‘£ğ¶subscriptproductsuperscriptğ‘£â€²ğ¸1subscriptğœŒconditionalsuperscriptğ‘£â€²ğ¶for allğ¸ğ¶\displaystyle p_{E\mid C}=\textstyle\prod_{v\in E}\rho_{v\mid C}\prod_{v^{% \prime}\notin E}(1-\rho_{v^{\prime}\mid C}),\quad\text{for all}~{}E\subseteq C,italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆˆ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‰ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , for all italic_E âŠ† italic_C ,

i.e., the events {vâˆˆE}ğ‘£ğ¸\{v\in E\}{ italic_v âˆˆ italic_E } are independent Bernoulli random variables parameterized by probabilities Ïvâˆ£C=ğâ¢(vâˆˆEâˆ£C)subscriptğœŒconditionalğ‘£ğ¶ğğ‘£conditionalğ¸ğ¶\rho_{v\mid C}=\mathbf{P}(v\in E\mid C)italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_P ( italic_v âˆˆ italic_E âˆ£ italic_C ), vâˆˆCğ‘£ğ¶v\in Citalic_v âˆˆ italic_C. We also require that, conditioned on Cğ¶Citalic_C, the expected size of the recommended set Eğ¸Eitalic_E is at most kâˆˆâ„•ğ‘˜â„•k\in\mathbb{N}italic_k âˆˆ blackboard_N, i.e.:

(21) ğ”¼Eâ¢[|E|âˆ£C]subscriptğ”¼ğ¸delimited-[]conditionalğ¸ğ¶\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{E}[|E|\mid C]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_E | âˆ£ italic_C ] â‰¤k,or, equivalenty,âˆ‘vâˆˆCÏvâˆ£Câ‰¤k,for allâ¢Câˆˆğ’.formulae-sequenceabsentğ‘˜or, equivalentyformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘£ğ¶subscriptğœŒconditionalğ‘£ğ¶ğ‘˜for allğ¶ğ’\displaystyle\leq k,~{}\text{or, equivalenty},~{}\textstyle\sum_{v\in C}\rho_{% v\mid C}\leq k,~{}\text{for all}~{}C\in\mathcal{C}.â‰¤ italic_k , or, equivalenty , âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆˆ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_k , for all italic_C âˆˆ caligraphic_C .

The set ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P comprises all distributions of formÂ (20) for which ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï satisfies Eq.Â (21).

Bounded cardinality policies ensure that the cardinality of recommendations |E|ğ¸|E|| italic_E | is at most kğ‘˜kitalic_k, but describing them requires mâ‰¡âˆ‘Câˆˆğ’(|C|k)ğ‘šsubscriptğ¶ğ’binomialğ¶ğ‘˜m\equiv\sum_{C\in\mathcal{C}}{|C|\choose k}italic_m â‰¡ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( binomial start_ARG | italic_C | end_ARG start_ARG italic_k end_ARG ) parameters; this is practical only for small kğ‘˜kitalic_k. Independent sampling policies require mâ€²â‰¡âˆ‘Câˆˆğ’|C|superscriptğ‘šâ€²subscriptğ¶ğ’ğ¶m^{\prime}\equiv\sum_{C\in\mathcal{C}}|C|italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¡ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_C | parameters. This polynomial in the number of in nğ‘›nitalic_n if, e.g., ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C is a partition of Î©âˆ–HÎ©ğ»\Omega\setminus Hroman_Î© âˆ– italic_H. However, independent sampling constrains cardinality only in expectation.

Top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k Recommendations. A simple, intuitive deterministic policy is the top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k recommendations policy [karypis2001evaluation, deshpande2004item, cremonesi2010performance]. Given Cğ¶Citalic_C and budget kğ‘˜kitalic_k, the policy recommends the kğ‘˜kitalic_k top-scoring items vâˆˆCğ‘£ğ¶v\in Citalic_v âˆˆ italic_C, w.r.t.Â some scores svâˆˆâ„+subscriptğ‘ ğ‘£subscriptâ„s_{v}\in\mathbb{R}_{+}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT quantifying a userâ€™s preference toward vğ‘£vitalic_v,

Formally, given Cğ¶Citalic_C and kğ‘˜kitalic_k, the top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k recommendation is given by:

(22) ECâˆ—=argâ¡maxEâˆˆğ’ŸCsE,subscriptsuperscriptğ¸ğ¶subscriptğ¸subscriptğ’Ÿğ¶subscriptğ‘ ğ¸\displaystyle E^{*}_{C}=\textstyle\mathop{\arg\,\max}_{E\in\mathcal{D}_{C}}s_{% E},italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = start_BIGOP roman_arg roman_max end_BIGOP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

be the highest-scoring subset of Cğ¶Citalic_C of size at most kğ‘˜kitalic_k. As sEsubscriptğ‘ ğ¸s_{E}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a modular function, the greedy algorithm that starts from an empty set and iteratively traverses Cğ¶Citalic_C and adds the highest-scoring items in the solution is in fact optimal, and produces ECâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ¸ğ¶E^{*}_{C}italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in polynomial time.

We note that this deterministic policy is included in ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P, when the latter is given either bounded cardinality and independent sampling settings. In the bounded cardinality setting, the top-k policy is captured by the Dirac distribution on Eâˆ—superscriptğ¸E^{*}italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i.e., Ï€Eâˆ—=1subscriptğœ‹superscriptğ¸1\pi_{E^{*}}=1italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 and 0 everywhere else. In the independent sampling case, it is captured by policy in which Ïvâˆ£C=1subscriptğœŒconditionalğ‘£ğ¶1\rho_{v\mid C}=1italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 for all vâˆˆEâˆ—ğ‘£superscriptğ¸v\in E^{*}italic_v âˆˆ italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and Ïvâˆ£C=0subscriptğœŒconditionalğ‘£ğ¶0\rho_{v\mid C}=0italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 for all vâˆ‰Eâˆ—ğ‘£superscriptğ¸v\not\in E^{*}italic_v âˆ‰ italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Conversely, an optimization over policies Ï€âˆˆğ’«ğœ‹ğ’«\pi\in\mathcal{P}italic_Ï€ âˆˆ caligraphic_P, with ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P defined by Eqs.Â (19) orÂ Â (20)â€“(21), the top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k policy is included as a valid policy.

Appendix B Proof of Thm.Â 3.4

Observe that by Eq.Â (4) the objective is given by

f0â¢(Ï€)=ğ”¼E,Câ¢[gâ¢(sE)]â¢(1+Î»â¢sHsÎ©)âˆ’Î»â¢sHsÎ©.subscriptğ‘“0ğœ‹subscriptğ”¼ğ¸ğ¶delimited-[]ğ‘”subscriptğ‘ ğ¸1ğœ†subscriptğ‘ ğ»subscriptğ‘ Î©ğœ†subscriptğ‘ ğ»subscriptğ‘ Î©f_{0}(\pi)=\mathbb{E}_{E,C}\left[g(s_{E})\right]\left(1+\frac{\lambda s_{H}}{s% _{\Omega}}\right)-\lambda\frac{s_{H}}{s_{\Omega}}.italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_g ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ( 1 + divide start_ARG italic_Î» italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) - italic_Î» divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG .

As the remaining quantities do not depend on Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€, to maximize f0subscriptğ‘“0f_{0}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it suffices to maximize

(23) f0â€²â¢(Ï€)â‰¡ğ”¼E,Câ¢[gâ¢(sE)]=âˆ‘Câˆ‘EâŠ†Cgâ¢(sE)â¢pEâˆ£Câ¢pC,superscriptsubscriptğ‘“0â€²ğœ‹subscriptğ”¼ğ¸ğ¶delimited-[]ğ‘”subscriptğ‘ ğ¸subscriptğ¶subscriptğ¸ğ¶ğ‘”subscriptğ‘ ğ¸subscriptğ‘conditionalğ¸ğ¶subscriptğ‘ğ¶\displaystyle f_{0}^{\prime}(\pi)\equiv\mathbb{E}_{E,C}\left[g(s_{E})\right]=% \textstyle\sum_{C}\sum_{E\subseteq C}g(s_{E})p_{E\mid C}p_{C},italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ ) â‰¡ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E , italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_g ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E âŠ† italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

which is exactly pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In other words, for any Î»â‰¥0ğœ†0\lambda\geq 0italic_Î» â‰¥ 0, the optimal policy Ï€âˆˆğ’«ğœ‹ğ’«\pi\in\mathcal{P}italic_Ï€ âˆˆ caligraphic_P is the one that minimizes the click-through rate, as captured by pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Consider first the case where ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is given by Eq.Â (19) (i.e., the bounded cardinality setting). Given a set Câˆˆğ’ğ¶ğ’C\in\mathcal{C}italic_C âˆˆ caligraphic_C, let

(25b) subj.Â to::subj.Â toabsent\displaystyle\text{subj.~{}to}:subj. to : âˆ‘Eâˆˆğ’ŸCpEâˆ£C=1.subscriptğ¸subscriptğ’Ÿğ¶subscriptğ‘conditionalğ¸ğ¶1\displaystyle\quad\textstyle\sum_{E\in\mathcal{D}_{C}}p_{E\mid C}=1.âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 .

Each of these problems is a linear program. Hence, by the fundamental theorem of linear programming, there exists an optimal solution that is an extremum of these constraints in Eq.Â (26b), which is a Dirac distribution on a set EâŠ†Cğ¸ğ¶E\subseteq Citalic_E âŠ† italic_C. The monotonicity of gâ¢(â‹…)ğ‘”â‹…g(\cdot)italic_g ( â‹… ), as a function of Eğ¸Eitalic_E implies that the largest value is attained at the Eâˆˆğ’ŸCğ¸subscriptğ’Ÿğ¶E\in\mathcal{D}_{C}italic_E âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with the largest sEsubscriptğ‘ ğ¸s_{E}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, namely Eâˆ—=argâ¡maxEâˆˆğ’ŸsEsuperscriptğ¸subscriptğ¸ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ¸E^{*}=\textstyle\mathop{\arg\,\max}_{E\in\mathcal{D}}s_{E}italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = start_BIGOP roman_arg roman_max end_BIGOP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E âˆˆ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the theorem follows.

Consider next the case where ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is given by Eqs.Â (20)â€“(21) (i.e., the independent sampling setting). Assume now that, in addition to non-decreasing, gğ‘”gitalic_g is also concave. Observe that, as a result, (i) as a function of set Eğ¸Eitalic_E, function sEsubscriptğ‘ ğ¸s_{E}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a modular function with non-negative weights svsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘£s_{v}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, vâˆˆEğ‘£ğ¸v\in Eitalic_v âˆˆ italic_E, and (ii) gâ¢(sE)ğ‘”subscriptğ‘ ğ¸g(s_{E})italic_g ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a monotone (non-decreasing) submodular function of set Eğ¸Eitalic_E.

For the same reasons as above, the optimization is again separable over parameters ÏC=[Ïvâˆ£C]vâˆˆCsubscriptğœŒğ¶subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğœŒconditionalğ‘£ğ¶ğ‘£ğ¶\rho_{C}=[\rho_{v\mid C}]_{v\in C}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆˆ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT conditioned on Cğ¶Citalic_C, and reduces to |ğ’|ğ’|\mathcal{C}|| caligraphic_C | independent problems of the form:

Appendix C Proof of LemmaÂ 4.1

Observe that, setting u=uâ¢(t)ğ‘¢ğ‘¢ğ‘¡u=u(t)italic_u = italic_u ( italic_t ), by Eq.Â (8) we have

Î”â¢uÎ”ğ‘¢\displaystyle\Delta uroman_Î” italic_u =ğ”¼â¢[Î±vâ¢(t)â¢(vâ¢(t)âˆ’u)]+Î²â¢(u0âˆ’u)absentğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ›¼ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğ‘£ğ‘¡ğ‘¢ğ›½subscriptğ‘¢0ğ‘¢\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\left[\alpha_{v(t)}\left(v(t)-u\right)\right]+\beta% \left(u_{0}-u\right)= blackboard_E [ italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v ( italic_t ) - italic_u ) ] + italic_Î² ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_u )
=(Î±ğ™·â¢âˆ‘vâˆˆHpvâ¢(vâˆ’u)+Î±ğ™½ğ™·â¢âˆ‘vâˆ‰Hpvâ¢(vâˆ’u))+Î²â¢(u0âˆ’u)absentsubscriptğ›¼ğ™·subscriptğ‘£ğ»subscriptğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘¢subscriptğ›¼ğ™½ğ™·subscriptğ‘£ğ»subscriptğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘¢ğ›½subscriptğ‘¢0ğ‘¢\displaystyle=\left(\alpha_{\mathtt{H}}\sum_{v\in H}p_{v}(v-u)+\alpha_{\mathtt% {NH}}\sum_{v\notin H}p_{v}(v-u)\right)+\beta\left(u_{0}-u\right)= ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆˆ italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v - italic_u ) + italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ‰ italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v - italic_u ) ) + italic_Î² ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_u )

The lemma follows by setting Î”â¢u=0Î”ğ‘¢0\Delta u=0roman_Î” italic_u = 0 and solving w.r.t.Â uğ‘¢uitalic_u. âˆ

Appendix D Multinomial Logit (MNL) Model.

We give here a more detailed description of the standard multinomial logit (MNL). MNL special case of the Plackett-Luce model, and it is popular in modeling user choices in recommender, search engine, and ad display settings [danaf2019online, chaptini2005use, yang2011collaborative]. This is precisely because it has several useful and natural properties. First, it is a natural generalization of matrix factorization [koren2009matrix] from ratings to choices, as scores depend on the inner product vâŠ¤â¢usuperscriptğ‘£topğ‘¢v^{\top}uitalic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u (i.e., how well item and user profiles are â€œalignedâ€). It is also a natural extension of â€œsoft-maxâ€, allowing for a no-choice alternative. We elaborate further in these connections below.

Formally, under MNL, for every vâˆˆÎ©ğ‘£Î©v\in\Omegaitalic_v âˆˆ roman_Î©, the non-negative score svâˆˆâ„+subscriptğ‘ ğ‘£superscriptâ„s_{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{+}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT quantifying a userâ€™s preference toward vğ‘£vitalic_v is

(29) svâ‰¡evâŠ¤â¢u,subscriptğ‘ ğ‘£superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘£topğ‘¢\displaystyle s_{v}\equiv e^{v^{\top}u},italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¡ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

i.e., it is parameterized by both the item profile vâˆˆâ„dğ‘£superscriptâ„ğ‘‘v\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_v âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as well as by a user profile uâˆˆâ„dğ‘¢superscriptâ„ğ‘‘u\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_u âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Moreover, the conditional probability pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºâˆ£Esubscriptğ‘conditionalğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºğ¸p_{\mathtt{CLK}\mid E}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK âˆ£ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is given: by

(30) gâ¢(SE)â‰¡sEsE+c.ğ‘”subscriptğ‘†ğ¸subscriptğ‘ ğ¸subscriptğ‘ ğ¸ğ‘\displaystyle g(S_{E})\equiv\frac{s_{E}}{s_{E}+c}~{}.italic_g ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¡ divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c end_ARG .

where câ‰¥0ğ‘0c\geq 0italic_c â‰¥ 0 is a non-negative constant. The remaining probabilities are given again by the Plackett-Luce model (Eq.Â (2)), with scores determined by (5).

In particular, conditioned on recommendation Eğ¸Eitalic_E, the probability that the user selects (i.e., clicks) on item vâˆˆEğ‘£ğ¸v\in Eitalic_v âˆˆ italic_E is given by:

(31) pvâˆ§ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºâˆ£E=svsE+c,forÂ â¢vâˆˆE,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ğ‘£conditionalğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºğ¸subscriptğ‘ ğ‘£subscriptğ‘ ğ¸ğ‘forÂ ğ‘£ğ¸\displaystyle p_{v\land\mathtt{CLK}\mid E}=\frac{s_{v}}{s_{E}+c},\quad\text{% for }v\in E,italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ§ typewriter_CLK âˆ£ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c end_ARG , for italic_v âˆˆ italic_E ,

where câ‰¥0ğ‘0c\geq 0italic_c â‰¥ 0 is a non-negative constant. In other words, the probability that vâˆˆEğ‘£ğ¸v\in Eitalic_v âˆˆ italic_E is selected is proportional to svâˆˆâ„+subscriptğ‘ ğ‘£superscriptâ„s_{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{+}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and is, in effect, a â€œsoft-maxâ€ over inner products vâŠ¤â¢usuperscriptğ‘£topğ‘¢v^{\top}uitalic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u, vâˆˆEğ‘£ğ¸v\in Eitalic_v âˆˆ italic_E, with cğ‘citalic_c controling the no-choice alternative.

Appendix E Proof of Thm.Â 4.2

We have

so |âˆ‚Giâ¢(p)âˆ‚pv|â‰¤(3â¢Î´+â€–u0â€–)â¢Î±ğ™·Î±ğ™½ğ™·+Î²subscriptğºğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘£3ğ›¿normsubscriptğ‘¢0subscriptğ›¼ğ™·subscriptğ›¼ğ™½ğ™·ğ›½\left|\frac{\partial G_{i}(p)}{\partial p_{v}}\right|\leq\frac{(3\delta+\|u_{0% }\|)\alpha_{\mathtt{H}}}{\alpha_{\mathtt{NH}}+\beta}| divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | â‰¤ divide start_ARG ( 3 italic_Î´ + âˆ¥ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ ) italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î² end_ARG. We thus conclude that

(35) â€–Gâ¢(p)âˆ’Gâ¢(pâ€²)â€–â‰¤(3â¢Î´+â€–u0â€–)â¢Î±Hâ¢nâ¢dÎ±ğ™½ğ™·+Î²â¢â€–pâˆ’pâ€²â€–,for allâ¢p,pâ€²âˆˆ[0,1]n.formulae-sequencenormğºğ‘ğºsuperscriptğ‘â€²3ğ›¿normsubscriptğ‘¢0subscriptğ›¼ğ»ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptğ›¼ğ™½ğ™·ğ›½normğ‘superscriptğ‘â€²for allğ‘superscriptğ‘â€²superscript01ğ‘›\displaystyle\|G(p)-G(p^{\prime})\|\leq\frac{(3\delta+\|u_{0}\|)\alpha_{H}% \sqrt{nd}}{\alpha_{\mathtt{NH}}+\beta}\|p-p^{\prime}\|,\quad\text{for all}~{}p% ,p^{\prime}\in[0,1]^{n}.âˆ¥ italic_G ( italic_p ) - italic_G ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ â‰¤ divide start_ARG ( 3 italic_Î´ + âˆ¥ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ ) italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_n italic_d end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î² end_ARG âˆ¥ italic_p - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ , for all italic_p , italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

To see that the map pğ‘pitalic_p is also Lipschitz, observe that, by (27)

We thus have that, for all u,uâ€²âˆˆâ„dğ‘¢superscriptğ‘¢â€²superscriptâ„ğ‘‘u,u^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_u , italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,

(46) â€–Fâ¢(u)âˆ’Fâ¢(uâ€²)â€–â‰¤Lâ‹…â€–uâˆ’uâ€²â€–,normğ¹ğ‘¢ğ¹superscriptğ‘¢â€²â‹…ğ¿normğ‘¢superscriptğ‘¢â€²\displaystyle\|F(u)-F(u^{\prime})\|\leq L\cdot\|u-u^{\prime}\|,âˆ¥ italic_F ( italic_u ) - italic_F ( italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_L â‹… âˆ¥ italic_u - italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ ,

where L=(3â¢Î´2+â€–u0â€–â¢Î´)â¢5â¢nâ¢dâ¢Î±HÎ±ğ™½ğ™·+Î²<1ğ¿3superscriptğ›¿2normsubscriptğ‘¢0ğ›¿5ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptğ›¼ğ»subscriptğ›¼ğ™½ğ™·ğ›½1L=(3\delta^{2}+\|u_{0}\|\delta)\frac{5nd\alpha_{H}}{\alpha_{\mathtt{NH}}+\beta% }<1italic_L = ( 3 italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âˆ¥ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Î´ ) divide start_ARG 5 italic_n italic_d italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î² end_ARG < 1 if Î´<16â¢(â€–u0â€–2+12â¢Î±ğ™½ğ™·+Î²5â¢nâ¢dâ¢Î±Hâˆ’â€–u0â€–)ğ›¿16superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘¢0212subscriptğ›¼ğ™½ğ™·ğ›½5ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptğ›¼ğ»normsubscriptğ‘¢0\delta<\frac{1}{6}\left(\sqrt{\|u_{0}\|^{2}+12\frac{\alpha_{\mathtt{NH}}+\beta% }{5nd\alpha_{H}}}-\|u_{0}\|\right)italic_Î´ < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 6 end_ARG ( square-root start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 12 divide start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î² end_ARG start_ARG 5 italic_n italic_d italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG - âˆ¥ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ ) âˆ

Thm.Â 4.2 along with the Banach fixed-point theoremÂ [banach1922operations] imply that a stationary profile exists and is unique. Most importantly, it can be found by the following iterative process. Starting from any uÂ¯0âˆˆâ„dsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘¢0superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\bar{u}^{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the iterations

are guaranteed to converge to the unique fixed-point uÂ¯âˆ—superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¢\bar{u}^{*}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of Eq.Â (10).

The Banach fixed-point theorem also implies that convergence happens exponentially fast. To see this, observe that, for L<1ğ¿1L<1italic_L < 1 the Lipschitz parameter of Fğ¹Fitalic_F,

for all â„“âˆˆâ„•â„“â„•\ell\in\mathbb{N}roman_â„“ âˆˆ blackboard_N.

Appendix F Proof of Thm.Â 4.3

Consider a setting where candidate set is always the entire catalog, i.e., C=Î©ğ¶Î©C=\Omegaitalic_C = roman_Î©. Set Î±ğ™½ğ™·=Î±ğ™·subscriptğ›¼ğ™½ğ™·subscriptğ›¼ğ™·\alpha_{\mathtt{NH}}=\alpha_{\mathtt{H}}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Î²=0ğ›½0\beta=0italic_Î² = 0. Set cğ‘citalic_c to be small enough so that gâ¢(sv0)>gâ¢(sv1)=0.8ğ‘”subscriptğ‘ subscriptğ‘£0ğ‘”subscriptğ‘ subscriptğ‘£10.8g(s_{v_{0}})>g(s_{v_{1}})=0.8italic_g ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > italic_g ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 0.8, i.e., so that irrespective of the recommendation, the recommended item has a high probability of being selected.

By Thm.Â 3.4, in its first iteration, Alg.Â (14) will recommend v0subscriptğ‘£0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as between the two options (v0subscriptğ‘£0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), it has the highest score. Under this recommendation policy, function Fğ¹Fitalic_F will be an interpolation between the three items, with the weight of v0subscriptğ‘£0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT being larger than 0.80.80.80.8. This means that the first application of Fğ¹Fitalic_F to u0subscriptğ‘¢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will produce a vector that will contain a high value (at least 0.6â¢B20.6subscriptğµ20.6B_{2}0.6 italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) on the second coordinate, and a negative value (at most âˆ’0.6â¢B20.6subscriptğµ2-0.6B_{2}- 0.6 italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) on the third coordinate. Repeated applications of Fğ¹Fitalic_F will make the contribution of v0subscriptğ‘£0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and vğ™·subscriptğ‘£ğ™·v_{\mathtt{H}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT higher, simultaneously suppressing the contribution of v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as the latter will have a score eâˆ’Î˜â¢(B22)superscriptğ‘’Î˜superscriptsubscriptğµ22e^{-\Theta(B_{2}^{2})}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - roman_Î˜ ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. As a result, the fixed point uÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¢\bar{u}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG will contain a larger contribution from v0subscriptğ‘£0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and vğ™·subscriptğ‘£ğ™·v_{\mathtt{H}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and, hence, the second coordinate will be positive and of order Î˜â¢(B2)Î˜subscriptğµ2\Theta(B_{2})roman_Î˜ ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), while the third coordinate will be negative and of order âˆ’Î˜â¢(B2)Î˜subscriptğµ2-\Theta(B_{2})- roman_Î˜ ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Thus, in the next iteration of the alternating optimization algorithm, v0subscriptğ‘£0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will again be selected as an optimal recommendation, and the algorithm will terminate (as uÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¢\bar{u}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG/Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€) will again be the same). At this operating point, however, as uÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¢\bar{u}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG has a non-zero, positive second coordinate, the probability of harm will be non-zero. In fact, it will be arbitrarily close to 1-pv0subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘£0p_{v_{0}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as the probability of selecting of v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will be negligible. Moreover, pv0subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘£0p_{v_{0}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will be bounded away from 1, as the probability of organic selection of v0subscriptğ‘£0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and vğ™·subscriptğ‘£ğ™·v_{\mathtt{H}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will be comparable for large B2subscriptğµ2B_{2}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (approximately â‰ˆ0.5absent0.5\approx 0.5â‰ˆ 0.5).

A very different behavior will occur however if v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is recommended. By our choice of cğ‘citalic_c, this will again be selected with probability >0.8absent0.8>0.8> 0.8, and repeated applications of Fğ¹Fitalic_F will lead to a uÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¢\bar{u}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG that has a Î¸B2subscriptğœƒsubscriptğµ2\theta_{B_{2}}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT For the same reasons, uÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¢\bar{u}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG will have a high positive value (Î˜â¢(B1)Î˜subscriptğµ1\Theta(B_{1})roman_Î˜ ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )) on the last coordinate and a high negative value (-Î˜â¢(B2)Î˜subscriptğµ2\Theta(B_{2})roman_Î˜ ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )) on the second coordinate. As a result, the probability (organic) selection of both v0subscriptğ‘£0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will be arbitrarily small under the stationary profile constructed by this recommendation policy.

The (approximate) symmetry between recommending v0subscriptğ‘£0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the uÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¢\bar{u}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARGs they lead to imply that these two policies will have a very similar pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; in contrast, they will have very different pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: this is precisely because with the first the probability of selecting vğ™·subscriptğ‘£ğ™·v_{\mathtt{H}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is non-negligible and comparable to the one selecting v0subscriptğ‘£0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, whereas with the second pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is negligible. Hence, by appropriately setting Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î», we can make the gap between the utilities constructed by two polices arbitrarily large. âˆ

Appendix G Gradient Computations

G.1. Bounded Cardinality Setting

    where

    (50) âˆ‚Giâ¢(p)âˆ‚pv=(â¢34â¢)Î±vâ¢âˆ‘vâ€²âˆˆÎ©(viâˆ’viâ€²)â¢Î±vâ€²â¢pvâ€²+Î±vâ¢Î²â¢(viâˆ’u0)(Î²+âˆ‘vâ€²âˆˆÎ©Î±vâ€²â¢pvâ€²)2,superscriptitalic-(34italic-)subscriptğºğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘£subscriptğ›¼ğ‘£subscriptsuperscriptğ‘£â€²Î©subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–â€²subscriptğ›¼superscriptğ‘£â€²subscriptğ‘superscriptğ‘£â€²subscriptğ›¼ğ‘£ğ›½subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¢0superscriptğ›½subscriptsuperscriptğ‘£â€²Î©subscriptğ›¼superscriptğ‘£â€²subscriptğ‘superscriptğ‘£â€²2\displaystyle\frac{\partial G_{i}(p)}{\partial p_{v}}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle% \eqref{eq:dg}}}{{=}}\frac{\alpha_{v}\sum_{v^{\prime}\in\Omega}(v_{i}-v_{i}^{% \prime})\alpha_{v^{\prime}}p_{v^{\prime}}+\alpha_{v}\beta(v_{i}-u_{0})}{(\beta% +\sum_{v^{\prime}\in\Omega}\alpha_{v^{\prime}}p_{v^{\prime}})^{2}},divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG italic_( italic_) end_ARG end_RELOP divide start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_Î© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT -     (52)     (53) âˆ‚âˆ‚uÂ¯jâ¢(svâˆ‘vâ€²âˆˆEsvâ€²+c)=(â¢39â¢)svâ‹…(âˆ‘vâ€²âˆˆE(vjâˆ’vjâ€²)â¢svâ€²+câ¢vj)(âˆ‘vâ€²âˆˆEsvâ€²+c)2,superscriptitalic-(39italic-)subscriptÂ¯ğ‘¢ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ ğ‘£subscriptsuperscriptğ‘£â€²ğ¸subscriptğ‘ superscriptğ‘£â€²ğ‘â‹…subscriptğ‘ ğ‘£subscriptsuperscriptğ‘£â€²ğ¸subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—â€²subscriptğ‘ superscriptğ‘£â€²ğ‘subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘£â€²ğ¸subscriptğ‘ superscriptğ‘£â€²ğ‘2\displaystyle\frac{\partial}{\partial\bar{u}_{j}}\left(\frac{s_{v}}{\sum_{v^{% \prime}\in E}s_{v^{\prime}}+c}\right)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\eqref{eq:dsv1}}}{% {=}}\frac{s_{v}\cdot(\sum_{v^{\prime}\in E}(v_{j}-v_{j}^{\prime})s_{v^{\prime}% }+cv_{j})}{(\sum_{v^{\prime}\in E}s_{v^{\prime}}+c)^{2}},divide start_ARG âˆ‚ end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ( divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c end_ARG ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG italic_( italic_) end_ARG end_RELOP divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT -     =câˆ‘vâ€²âˆˆÎ©svâ€²â‹…svâ¢(âˆ‘vâ€²âˆˆE(vjâˆ’vjâ€²)â¢svâ€²+câ¢vj)(âˆ‘vâ€²âˆˆEsvâ€²+c)2absentâ‹…ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘£â€²Î©subscriptğ‘ superscriptğ‘£â€²subscriptğ‘ ğ‘£subscriptsuperscriptğ‘£â€²ğ¸subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—â€²subscriptğ‘ superscriptğ‘£â€²ğ‘subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘£â€²ğ¸subscriptğ‘ superscriptğ‘£â€²ğ‘2\displaystyle\quad=\frac{c}{\sum_{v^{\prime}\in\Omega}s_{v^{\prime}}}\cdot% \frac{s_{v}(\sum_{v^{\prime}\in E}(v_{j}-v_{j}^{\prime})s_{v^{\prime}}+cv_{j})% }{(\sum_{v^{\prime}\in E}s_{v^{\prime}}+c)^{2}}= divide start_ARG italic_c end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_Î© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG â‹… divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG
    (54) âˆ’svâˆ‘vâ€²âˆˆEsvâ€²+câ‹…câ‹…(âˆ‘vâ€²âˆˆÎ©vjâ€²â¢svâ€²)(âˆ‘vâ€²âˆˆÎ©svâ€²)2.â‹…subscriptğ‘ ğ‘£subscriptsuperscriptğ‘£â€²ğ¸subscriptğ‘ superscriptğ‘£â€²ğ‘â‹…ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘£â€²Î©subscriptsuperscriptğ‘£â€²ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ superscriptğ‘£â€²superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘£â€²Î©subscriptğ‘ superscriptğ‘£â€²2\displaystyle\quad~{}~{}~{}~{}-\frac{s_{v}}{\sum_{v^{\prime}\in E}s_{v^{\prime% }}+c}\cdot\frac{c\cdot(\sum_{v^{\prime}\in\Omega}v^{\prime}_{j}s_{v^{\prime}})% }{(\sum_{v^{\prime}\in\Omega}s_{v^{\prime}})^{2}}.- divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_c end_ARG â‹… divide start_ARG italic_c â‹… ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_Î© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_Î© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG .

    âˆ‡Ï€Fâ¢(Ï€,uÂ¯)âˆˆâ„dÃ—msubscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹ğ¹ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘š\nabla_{\pi}F(\pi,\bar{u})\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times m}âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d Ã— italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the Jacobian of Fğ¹Fitalic_F w.r.t.Â its first argument, (i.e.,Â Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€). The coordinates of this matrix are given by:

    (55) âˆ‚Fiâˆ‚pEâˆ£C=(â¢32â¢)âˆ‘vâˆ‚Giâ¢(p)âˆ‚pvâ‹…âˆ‚pvâˆ‚pEâˆ£C,forâ¢iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,d},EâˆˆDC,Câˆˆğ’,formulae-sequencesuperscriptitalic-(32italic-)subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğ‘conditionalğ¸ğ¶subscriptğ‘£â‹…subscriptğºğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘£subscriptğ‘ğ‘£subscriptğ‘conditionalğ¸ğ¶formulae-sequenceforğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘‘formulae-sequenceğ¸subscriptğ·ğ¶ğ¶ğ’\displaystyle\frac{\partial F_{i}}{\partial p_{E\mid C}}\stackrel{{% \scriptstyle\eqref{eq:gp}}}{{=}}\sum_{v}\frac{\partial G_{i}(p)}{\partial p_{v% }}\cdot\frac{\partial p_{v}}{\partial p_{E\mid C}},\quad\text{for}~{}i\in\{1,% \ldots,d\},E\in D_{C},C\in\mathcal{C},divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG italic_( italic_) end_ARG end_RELOP âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG â‹… divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , for italic_i âˆˆ { 1 , â€¦ , italic_d } , italic_E âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C âˆˆ caligraphic_C ,

    where âˆ‚Giâ¢(p)âˆ‚pvsubscriptğºğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘£\frac{\partial G_{i}(p)}{\partial p_{v}}divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG is again given by Eq.Â (50) and

    (56) âˆ‚pvâˆ‚pEâˆ£C=pCâ‹…pvâˆ£E,subscriptğ‘ğ‘£subscriptğ‘conditionalğ¸ğ¶â‹…subscriptğ‘ğ¶subscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘£ğ¸\displaystyle\frac{\partial p_{v}}{\partial p_{E\mid C}}=p_{C}\cdot p_{v\mid E},divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ£ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

for pvâˆ£Esubscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘£ğ¸p_{v\mid E}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ£ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as in Eq.Â (28).

Gradients of pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, the gradient âˆ‡Ï€pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºâ¢(Ï€,uÂ¯â¢(Ï€))âˆˆâ„msubscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹subscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹superscriptâ„ğ‘š\nabla_{\pi}p_{\mathtt{CLK}}(\pi,\bar{u}(\pi))\in\mathbb{R}^{m}âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ) ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will be:

(57) âˆ‡Ï€pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºâ¢(Ï€,uÂ¯â¢(Ï€))=âˆ‡Ï€pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºâ¢(Ï€,uÂ¯)+[âˆ‡Ï€uÂ¯â¢(Ï€)]âŠ¤â¢âˆ‡uÂ¯pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºâ¢(Ï€,uÂ¯),subscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹subscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹subscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹subscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢superscriptdelimited-[]subscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹topsubscriptâˆ‡Â¯ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢\displaystyle\nabla_{\pi}p_{\mathtt{CLK}}(\pi,\bar{u}(\pi))=\nabla_{\pi}p_{% \mathtt{CLK}}(\pi,\bar{u})+\left[\nabla_{\pi}\bar{u}(\pi)\right]^{\top}\nabla_% {\bar{u}}p_{\mathtt{CLK}}(\pi,\bar{u}),âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ) ) = âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ) + [ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ) ,

where the terms of the r.h.s.Â are as follows:

  • â€¢

    uÂ¯=uÂ¯â¢(Ï€)âˆˆâ„dÂ¯ğ‘¢Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\bar{u}=\bar{u}(\pi)\in\mathbb{R}^{d}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, computed via Eq.Â (13).

  • â€¢

    âˆ‡Ï€uÂ¯â¢(Ï€)âˆˆâ„dÃ—msubscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢ğœ‹superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘š\nabla_{\pi}\bar{u}(\pi)\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times m}âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï€ ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d Ã— italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the Jacobian of uÂ¯â¢(â‹…)Â¯ğ‘¢â‹…\bar{u}(\cdot)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( â‹… ), computed via Eq.Â (48).

    âˆ‡Ï€pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºâ¢(Ï€,uÂ¯)âˆˆâ„msubscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹subscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢superscriptâ„ğ‘š\nabla_{\pi}p_{\mathtt{CLK}}(\pi,\bar{u})\in\mathbb{R}^{m}âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the gradient of

    w.r.t.Â to its first argument (i.e., Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€). Its coordinates are given by:

Projected Gradient Ascent. Given the gradient, the PGA steps would be:

(66) Ï€â„“+1=ğ’«Î â¢(Ï€â„“+Î³â„“â¢âˆ‡Ï€fâ¢(Ï€k))subscriptğœ‹â„“1subscriptğ’«Î subscriptğœ‹â„“subscriptğ›¾â„“subscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹ğ‘“subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜\displaystyle\pi_{\ell+1}=\mathcal{P}_{\Pi}\left(\pi_{\ell}+\gamma_{\ell}% \nabla_{\pi}f(\pi_{k})\right)italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î  end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )

where

(67) ğ’«Î â¢(Ï€â€²)=argâ¡minÏ€âˆˆÎ â€–Ï€âˆ’Ï€â€–22subscriptğ’«Î superscriptğœ‹â€²subscriptğœ‹Î superscriptsubscriptnormğœ‹ğœ‹22\displaystyle{\mathcal{P}_{\Pi}}(\pi^{\prime})=\mathop{\arg\,\min}_{\pi\in\Pi}% \|\pi-\pi\|_{2}^{2}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î  end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = start_BIGOP roman_arg roman_min end_BIGOP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ âˆˆ roman_Î  end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Ï€ - italic_Ï€ âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

is the orthogonal projection to Î Î \Piroman_Î , given by Eq.Â (19). This projection is a quadratic optimization problem that can be solved through standard techniques, but because Î Î \Piroman_Î  is is the canonical simplex, it actually admits a strongly poly-time algorithm (see, e.g., [michelot1986finite]).

G.2. Independent Sampling Setting

Recall that, under the independent sampling setting, computing the optimal Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ thus reduces to computing the mâ€²â‰¡âˆ‘Câˆˆğ’|C|superscriptğ‘šâ€²subscriptğ¶ğ’ğ¶m^{\prime}\equiv\sum_{C\in\mathcal{C}}|C|italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¡ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_C | parameters in Ï=[Ïvâˆ£C]vâˆˆC,Câˆˆğ’ğœŒsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğœŒconditionalğ‘£ğ¶formulae-sequenceğ‘£ğ¶ğ¶ğ’\rho=[\rho_{v\mid C}]_{v\in C,C\in\mathcal{C}}italic_Ï = [ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆˆ italic_C , italic_C âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This comes with a computational advantage compared to the bounded cardinality setting; for example, if ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}caligraphic_C is a partition of Î©âˆ–HÎ©ğ»\Omega\setminus Hroman_Î© âˆ– italic_H, the number of parameters becomes linear (namely, nâ€²=nâˆ’hsuperscriptğ‘›â€²ğ‘›â„n^{\prime}=n-hitalic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_n - italic_h).

Given a set Câˆˆğ’ğ¶ğ’C\in\mathcal{C}italic_C âˆˆ caligraphic_C, let ÏC=[Ïvâˆ£C]vâˆˆCâˆˆâ„|C|subscriptğœŒğ¶subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğœŒconditionalğ‘£ğ¶ğ‘£ğ¶superscriptâ„ğ¶\rho_{C}=[\rho_{v\mid C}]_{v\in C}\in\mathbb{R}^{|C|}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆˆ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_C | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the vector of probabilities condition on the candidate set being Cğ¶Citalic_C. Then, for any set function z:2Câ†’â„:ğ‘§â†’superscript2ğ¶â„z:2^{C}\to\mathbb{R}italic_z : 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R, we can approximate ğ”¼ÏCâ¢[zâ¢(E)]subscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ¶delimited-[]ğ‘§ğ¸\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{C}}[z(E)]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_z ( italic_E ) ] via

(68) ğ”¼ÏC^â¢[zâ¢(E)]=1Nâ¢âˆ‘â„“=1Nzâ¢(Eâ„“),^subscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ¶delimited-[]ğ‘§ğ¸1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptâ„“1ğ‘ğ‘§subscriptğ¸â„“\displaystyle\widehat{\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{C}}}[z(E)]=\textstyle\frac{1}{N}\sum_{% \ell=1}^{N}z(E_{\ell}),over^ start_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG [ italic_z ( italic_E ) ] = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_z ( italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

where Eâ„“subscriptğ¸â„“E_{\ell}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, â„“=1,â€¦,Nâ„“1â€¦ğ‘\ell=1,\ldots,Nroman_â„“ = 1 , â€¦ , italic_N are i.i.d., sampled from the appropriate product form distribution (see Eq.Â (20)). Most importantly, we can also estimate the gradient âˆ‡ÏCğ”¼ÏCâ¢[zâ¢(E)]âˆˆâ„|C|subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœŒğ¶subscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ¶delimited-[]ğ‘§ğ¸superscriptâ„ğ¶\nabla_{\rho_{C}}\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{C}}[z(E)]\in\mathbb{R}^{|C|}âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_z ( italic_E ) ] âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_C | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT via

(69) âˆ‚âˆ‚Ïvâˆ£C^(ğ”¼ÏC[z(E)])=ğ”¼ÏC^[z(Eâˆª{v}âˆ’z(Eâˆ–{v})].\displaystyle\textstyle\widehat{\frac{\partial}{\partial\rho_{v\mid C}}}\left(% \mathbb{E}_{\rho_{C}}[z(E)]\right)=\widehat{\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{C}}}[z(E\cup\{v% \}-z(E\setminus\{v\})].over^ start_ARG divide start_ARG âˆ‚ end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG ( blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_z ( italic_E ) ] ) = over^ start_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG [ italic_z ( italic_E âˆª { italic_v } - italic_z ( italic_E âˆ– { italic_v } ) ] .

This is classic (see, e.g., [calinescu2011maximizing]) and has a long history of use in submodular optimization [calinescu2011maximizing, hassani2017gradient]. The function Zâ¢(Ï)=ğ”¼ÏCâ¢[zâ¢(E)]ğ‘ğœŒsubscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ¶delimited-[]ğ‘§ğ¸Z(\rho)=\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{C}}[z(E)]italic_Z ( italic_Ï ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_z ( italic_E ) ] is known as the multi-linear relaxation of zğ‘§zitalic_z, and Chernoff bounds can be used to characterize the quality of the above approximations; moreover, provided zğ‘§zitalic_z is bounded (which is indeed the case for all functions we compute here) a polynomial number of samples Nğ‘Nitalic_N is required for the above estimators to get within a given accuracy from the true expectation (see, e.g., Sec.Â 3 inÂ calinescu2011maximizing).

These sampling techniques can be applied directly to our independent sampling setting, again combined with an appropriate combination of chain rules the an appropriate evocation of the implicit function theorem.

Fixed-point Operator. Given ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï, the fixed point map whoâ€™s repetition gives uÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¢\bar{u}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG is given by:

(70) Fâ¢(Ï,u)=Gâ¢(pâ¢(Ï,u))ğ¹ğœŒğ‘¢ğºğ‘ğœŒğ‘¢\displaystyle F(\rho,u)=G(p(\rho,u))italic_F ( italic_Ï , italic_u ) = italic_G ( italic_p ( italic_Ï , italic_u ) )

where p:[0,1]âˆ‘Câˆˆğ’|C|Ã—â„dâ†’[0,1]n:ğ‘â†’superscript01subscriptğ¶ğ’ğ¶superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscript01ğ‘›p:[0,1]^{\sum_{C\in\mathcal{C}}|C|}\times\mathbb{R}^{d}\to[0,1]^{n}italic_p : [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C âˆˆ caligraphic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_C | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the map that produces the probabilities pvsubscriptğ‘ğ‘£p_{v}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, given by Eq.Â (27), and G:[0,1]nâ†’â„d:ğºâ†’superscript01ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘‘G:[0,1]^{n}\to\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_G : [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the map given by Eq.Â (33). Hence, GğºGitalic_G remains the same as in the bounded cardinality case, and the map pvsubscriptğ‘ğ‘£p_{v}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be computed by

(71) pv=ğ”¼Câ¢[ğ”¼ÏCâ¢[pvâˆ£E]]subscriptğ‘ğ‘£subscriptğ”¼ğ¶delimited-[]subscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ¶delimited-[]subscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘£ğ¸\displaystyle p_{v}=\mathbb{E}_{C}[\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{C}}[p_{v\mid E}]]italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ£ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ]

with pvâˆ£Esubscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘£ğ¸p_{v\mid E}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ£ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT given by Eq.Â (28), by replacing the expectation with the estimator given by Eq.Â (68).

Projected Gradient Ascent. Projected gradient ascent is defined by

(72) Ïk+1=ğ’«Râ¢(Ïk+Î³kâ¢âˆ‡Ïfâ¢(Ïk))subscriptğœŒğ‘˜1subscriptğ’«ğ‘…subscriptğœŒğ‘˜subscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜subscriptâˆ‡ğœŒğ‘“subscriptğœŒğ‘˜\displaystyle\rho_{k+1}=\mathcal{P}_{R}\left(\rho_{k}+\gamma_{k}\nabla_{\rho}f% (\rho_{k})\right)italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )

where

(73) ğ’«Î â¢(Ïâ€²)=argâ¡minÏâˆˆRâ€–Ïâ€²âˆ’Ïâ€–22subscriptğ’«Î superscriptğœŒâ€²subscriptğœŒğ‘…superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptğœŒâ€²ğœŒ22\displaystyle{\mathcal{P}_{\Pi}}(\rho^{\prime})=\mathop{\arg\,\min}_{\rho\in R% }\|\rho^{\prime}-\rho\|_{2}^{2}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î  end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = start_BIGOP roman_arg roman_min end_BIGOP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï âˆˆ italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_Ï start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Ï âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

is the orthogonal projection to set Rğ‘…Ritalic_R, given by Eq.Â (21). This is again a projection to a rescaled simplex, and can be computed by, e.g., Michelotâ€™s algorithm [michelot1986finite].

Gradient of the uÂ¯â¢(â‹…)Â¯ğ‘¢â‹…\bar{u}(\cdot)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( â‹… ) Operator. The gradient of the uÂ¯â¢(â‹…)Â¯ğ‘¢â‹…\bar{u}(\cdot)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( â‹… ) operator, is again given by:

(74) âˆ‡ÏuÂ¯â¢(Ï)=âˆ’(âˆ‡uÂ¯Fâ¢(Ï,uÂ¯)âˆ’IdÃ—d)âˆ’1â‹…âˆ‡ÏFâ¢(Ï,uÂ¯)subscriptâˆ‡ğœŒÂ¯ğ‘¢ğœŒâ‹…superscriptsubscriptâˆ‡Â¯ğ‘¢ğ¹ğœŒÂ¯ğ‘¢subscriptğ¼ğ‘‘ğ‘‘1subscriptâˆ‡ğœŒğ¹ğœŒÂ¯ğ‘¢\displaystyle\nabla_{\rho}\bar{u}(\rho)=-\left(\nabla_{\bar{u}}F(\rho,\bar{u})% -I_{d\times d}\right)^{-1}\cdot\nabla_{\rho}F(\rho,\bar{u})âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_Ï ) = - ( âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_Ï , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ) - italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_Ï , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG )

Here

  • â€¢

    âˆ‡uÂ¯Fâ¢(Ï€,uÂ¯)âˆˆâ„dÃ—dsubscriptâˆ‡Â¯ğ‘¢ğ¹ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘‘\nabla_{\bar{u}}F(\pi,\bar{u})\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is computed exactly as in Eq.Â (49)â€“(54), the only difference being that the expectation:

    (75) âˆ‚pvâˆ‚uÂ¯j=ğ”¼Câ¢[ğ”¼ÏCâ¢[âˆ‚pv|Eâˆ‚uÂ¯j]]subscriptğ‘ğ‘£subscriptÂ¯ğ‘¢ğ‘—subscriptğ”¼ğ¶delimited-[]subscriptğ”¼subscriptğœŒğ¶delimited-[]subscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘£ğ¸subscriptÂ¯ğ‘¢ğ‘—\displaystyle\frac{\partial p_{v}}{\partial\bar{u}_{j}}=\mathbb{E}_{C}\left[% \mathbb{E}_{\rho_{C}}\left[\frac{\partial p_{v|E}}{\partial\bar{u}_{j}}\right]\right]divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v | italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ] ]

    is computed via the sampling estimator in (68).

    âˆ‡Ï€Fâ¢(Ï€,uÂ¯)âˆˆâ„dÃ—nsubscriptâˆ‡ğœ‹ğ¹ğœ‹Â¯ğ‘¢superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘›\nabla_{\pi}F(\pi,\bar{u})\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times n}âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_Ï€ , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d Ã— italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is computed as in Eq.Â (55)â€“(56), where

    (76) âˆ‚pvâˆ‚Ïv|mâ¢iâ¢dâ¢C=âˆ‚âˆ‚Ïvâˆ£Câ¢(ğ”¼â¢[pvâˆ£E])subscriptğ‘ğ‘£subscriptğœŒconditionalğ‘£ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ¶subscriptğœŒconditionalğ‘£ğ¶ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘£ğ¸\displaystyle\frac{\partial p_{v}}{\partial\rho_{v|midC}}=\frac{\partial}{% \partial\rho_{v\mid C}}\left(\mathbb{E}[p_{v\mid E}]\right)divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v | italic_m italic_i italic_d italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ£ italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ( blackboard_E [ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆ£ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] )

    is computed via the gradient sampling estimator in Eq.Â (69).

Appendix H Additional Experimental Details and Results

H.1. Experimental Setup

We join the MovieLens25m ratings, movies, and links csv files by movieId, and then join with the IMDB datasetÂ [IMDBParent] by the same column. We filter on the desired genre, and then select the top 100 movies with the highest number of ratings, and the subsequent top 1000 users by the number of these movies that they have rated. A matrix factorization model is trained using this user-movie ratings matrix with dimension 10 as well as additional user and item level biases. We use stochastic gradient descent over the mean squared error, with learning rate of 0.01, regularization parameter of 0.01, and 100 iterations. This process results in learned 12 dimensional user and item embeddings. The RMSE of these learned embeddings are as follows: Action: 1.39, Adventure: 1.49, Comedy: 1.54, Fantasy: 1.86, Sci-Fi: 1.59. For the simulations, we select a set of 100 users per genre u.a.r., with a fixed random seed of 42. Experiments were conducted on a CPU cluster with slurm management. To compute the embeddings, 100G of memory and 10 CPUs were requested. The matrix factorization implementation we used is a modified from an open source repository.222 https://github.com/albertauyeung/matrix-factorization-in-python

pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Calibration with cğ‘citalic_c. The parameter cğ‘citalic_c in the multinomial logit modelÂ (6) influences the effectiveness of our policies in garnering clicks and therefore guiding user dynamics. For any given sEsubscriptğ‘ ğ¸s_{E}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as câ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘c\to\inftyitalic_c â†’ âˆ, gâ†’0â†’ğ‘”0g\to 0italic_g â†’ 0. By calibrating cğ‘citalic_c, we can influence pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT so that our simulations are in a regime where harm matters. For each genre we take a random sample of 10 users, and compute the resulting pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT under the uniform and alternating policies, at steady state user dynamics. TableÂ 4 shows the results for each genre, and the chosen value of cğ‘citalic_c, for k=1ğ‘˜1k=1italic_k = 1 under the bounded cardinality setting. Our heuristic is to choose cğ‘citalic_c for each genre maximizing pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that pğ™²ğ™»ğ™º>0.5subscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™º0.5p_{\mathtt{CLK}}>0.5italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0.5 under the Alt policy.

Algorithm Implementation Details. Fixed-point operations (Eq.Â (13)) executed for at most Ï„=10ğœ10\tau=10italic_Ï„ = 10 iterations, and always converged within a 10âˆ’3superscript10310^{-3}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT tolerance, irrespective of whether conditions of Thm.Â 4.2 were satisfied. Unless otherwise noted, all recommendation policies operate in the Bounded Cardinality setting (Sec.Â 4.2).

Additional algorithm implementation details per algorithm are as follows:

  • â€¢

    Gradient-Based Algorithm (Grad). We implement a gradient-based algorithm solving Prob.Â (9) using the SLSQP implementation of SciPyÂ [2020SciPy-NMeth]. For the bounded cardinality setting, we encode constraints such that the sum of the policy vector is 1, and each entry of the policy vector is non-negative. For the independent sampling setting, we encode constraints such that the sum of the policy vector is kğ‘˜kitalic_k, and each entry lies within the interval [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ]. We set SLSQP precision tolerance to ftol=10âˆ’4absentsuperscript104=10^{-4}= 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Because this is a non-convex optimization problem, we start the SLSQP procedure at various starting points and choose the resulting policy which achieves the best objective. For starting points we use: U0 policy, Unif policy, Unif â€œinteriorâ€ policy (dividing the vector by 100 to reach an interior point of the constraints), 3 random initalizations such that the sum of the policy vector is 1, and 3 random â€œinteriorâ€ initalizations taking the previous random vector and dividing by 100.

  • â€¢

    Alternating Optimization (Alt). We also implement alternating optimizationÂ (Sec.Â 4.3) for 10 steps; in all our experiments, user profiles converged with tolerance less than 2.5Ã—10âˆ’32.5superscript1032.5\times 10^{-3}2.5 Ã— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, in â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT distance.

  • â€¢

    Static Profile Optimization (U0). As an additional baseline, we consider the policy maximizing the objective under a static user profile, i.e., Eq.Â (3) with user profile u0subscriptğ‘¢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  • â€¢

    Uniform Recommendations (Unif). We also implement recommending uniformly at random as a baseline. For the bounded cardinality setting, that is Ï€E=1/|ğ’Ÿ|,subscriptğœ‹ğ¸1ğ’Ÿ\pi_{E}=1/|\mathcal{D}|,italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 / | caligraphic_D | , for Eâˆˆğ’Ÿğ¸ğ’ŸE\in\mathcal{D}italic_E âˆˆ caligraphic_D, and Ïv=k/nâ€²subscriptğœŒğ‘£ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘›â€²\rho_{v}=k/n^{\prime}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k / italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, for vâˆˆÎ©âˆ–Hğ‘£Î©ğ»v\in\Omega\setminus Hitalic_v âˆˆ roman_Î© âˆ– italic_H, for the independent sampling setting.

Profile Evolution. We also implement the time evolution of a user profile under a given recommendation policy, always starting from u0subscriptğ‘¢0u_{0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We iterate over Eq.Â (â¢7â¢)italic-(7italic-)\eqref{eq:u}italic_( italic_) until â€–uâ¢(t+1)âˆ’uâ¢(t)â€–âˆ<10âˆ’3subscriptnormğ‘¢ğ‘¡1ğ‘¢ğ‘¡superscript103\|u(t+1)-u(t)\|_{\infty}<10^{-3}âˆ¥ italic_u ( italic_t + 1 ) - italic_u ( italic_t ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Programming and Experimental Environment. All code was written in Python 3.10, using numpy 1.21.5, pandas 1.5.2, and scipy 1.9.3. Experiments were conducted on a CPU cluster with slurm management. Each genre and experimental configuration was parallelized across users by running multiple slurm jobs. To learn the policies, 1G of memory and 5 CPUs were requested for each parallelized job.

H.2. Additional Experimental Results

Per-User Policy Performance Comparison. Fig.Â 8 shows the PDF of the difference between the objective attained by different policies minus the objective by attained by Grad, for the same experimental settings as in TableÂ 2. For the overwelming majority of users, the objective attained by other policies is below the ones attained by Grad. These insights are also reflected in the plots for pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, FiguresÂ 9 andÂ 10, respectively.

Understanding the Effect of Model Parameters. We plot the change in the objective as we modify parameters for different genres in FigureÂ 11. We observe the same patterns we saw in Fig.Â 4 for the Action genre. As the user coefficient Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² increases, we see a consistent degradation in performance for the policies (gradient, alternating) which account for user dynamics. This is expected as higher Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² makes a user more resistant to changing their initial profile. As the recommendation efficacy decreases (higher cğ‘citalic_c), we see that pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT decreases and pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT increases as users go to more ğ™¾ğšğ™¶ğ™¾ğšğ™¶\mathtt{ORG}typewriter_ORG interactions.

We also plot the corresponding pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT values in FiguresÂ 12 and FigureÂ 13, respectively. As we increase the harm penalty Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î» we see that pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT remain stable. We see an improved performance on the grad policy when Î»=0ğœ†0\lambda=0italic_Î» = 0 w.r.t. pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is counterintuitive. This could be either because the problem is highly non-convex, and none of the above solutions are guaranteed to be optimal, or because Grad finds a better tradeoff at improving pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT rather than directly minimizing pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, even when Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0italic_Î» > 0, precisely because of the relatively small value of pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT relative to pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In all cases, however, Grad acheives a higher pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and lower pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT than other policies.

We also plot the effect of increasing the ratio between Î±ğ™·/Î±ğ™½ğ™·subscriptğ›¼ğ™·subscriptğ›¼ğ™½ğ™·\alpha_{\mathtt{H}}/\alpha_{\mathtt{NH}}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_NH end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Fig.Â 14. As harmful content becomes more attractive, we see that the gradient collapses into alternating maximization. All policies also degrade in terms of pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as harmful content becomes more attractive, as shown in Figs.Â 15 andÂ 16, respectively.

Increasing the Recommendation Set Size kğ‘˜kitalic_k. TableÂ 5 gives the parameter values for kğ‘˜kitalic_k and cğ‘citalic_c for FiguresÂ 6,Â 17, andÂ 18, when either cğ‘citalic_c is fixed, or k/cğ‘˜ğ‘k/citalic_k / italic_c is fixed. We see in FiguresÂ 17 and Â 18 similar trends as was observed in FigureÂ 6 in the main paper. Increasing kğ‘˜kitalic_k while cğ‘citalic_c is fixed results in an increase in pğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºsubscriptğ‘ğ™²ğ™»ğ™ºp_{\mathtt{CLK}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_CLK end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and a resulting decrease in pğ™·subscriptğ‘ğ™·p_{\mathtt{H}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Generated on Fri Jun 14 09:49:56 2024 by LaTeXML
